Arrived too late for the tour but just wandering is fine. On a pleasant square near the old city. Nice shop and cafe.
Is a very good place to enjoy a good musical spectacle. It is a theater that has a very good acoustics and is among the best
Look for your choice and be taken away by the performance. Good ballet, nice concerts. One can only enjoy. If no play let the building take you away.

The oldest theatre is located in Plaza Independencia. This is an ornate and elegant performance venue. It has been refurbished and now offers superb acoustics. There are guided tours for visiting the inside of the theatre. However, the gift shop and museum are open to the public.
Huge and well build. It has guided tours at different times, for a ticket price that is more a symbolic thing than a charge. As you move on, a few actors will appear playing!
Very nice theatre opened in 1856 located in Montevideo's old town. I loved it!! there are guided tours or you can check the theatre's program/agenda

Opened 1856. Greeted at the door by English speaking guides. You must take a tour at specific times to enjoy. We just missed the tour at 16h00 and will definately return to attend.
I wasn't sure you could visit this place and how. But since I had to use the bathroom I walked in and ended up in a beautiful space with an art/costume exhibition. Just great!
Really very beautiful theater to visit . Specially if you are able to go on a guided tour . If in the city you should not miss if interested in art .
absolutely surprising! great show! really funny and well done!!!kids and adults really loved it! my 3 years old was fascinated ! the theater is very nice!!! is a copy of paris opera!!! we loved it!

wonderful piece of history in downtown Montevideo. and still offers shows from time to time. architecture on the outside and beautiful ornaments inside

I went on a tour of this old theatre-much older than the Teatro Colon in BA which I also visited. It was good to be taken around and to see the main auditorium and the small one too. Sadly no visit behind the scenes.

I took a tour on a Wednesday -- which was fortunate, because there is no charge for tours on Wednesdays. Tours were offered in Spanish, English, and Portuguese. The tour guides were all university students on an internship. The entire tour really made each guest feel welcome,

We were there on a Sunday afternoon. Three tours running concurrently: English, Spanish and Portuguese. It covered all the bases concerning a theatre: history, layout, society, and there was a bounus threatre in the back. It was well worth the very small fee and our time.

We were there on a monday, they were running guided tours in several languages [ including english] Be warned you have to pay the very small fee in uruguay pesos. This was a great visit of this beautiful theatre, more like an opera house. After the tour we visited their coffee

We took the English speaking tour of the theatre which took about an hour. Beautiful building and great to be able to see it from all levels and angles. The guide was very good and involved the participants by asking questions about our own experiences at home such as prices

The outside is very impressive and beautiful. We decided not to take the tour since we think it was in Spanish only. The young gentlemen at the door let us go to the gift shop and told us about an exhibit that was free. I think it was a weird one about Shakespearean costumes.

There are only certain days of the week and very limited times where you can have access to a guided tour. I have been trying for 3 years I'm a row to visit with no success. There is always "something" I give up.

In a city sea/ river iriented this artistical gem is located in the mainsquare Plaza Independencia. Opera, theather plays are commonly there. El Solís shows how different is Urguay from latinamerica. A must to go there and visit the place and later. There are in the nearby

We were the only English speakers and therefore ended up with our own private tour guide. He was brilliant and it was so interesting. He had done a History degree and really knew his stuff. We found this to be a great experience in Montevideo and thanks to our incredible tour

We turned up here expecting to just look around ourselves but found you had to join a tour. We were lucky as there was one starting at 5pm and it was only 60 pesos. We chose an English tour and the guide was friendly and knowledgeable. The tour lasted about 40 minutes - really

During January there are no theatre performances in the Theatre Solis so I decided to take the one hour tour. The story of the theatre is part of Montevideo's history and culture. During the tour you see a charming, random performance of two actors and meanwhile you enjoy the
We paid the $3 (only take Uruguay pesos) and did the English tour--- wow! They made it an experience with a little vignette. Beautiful building.
It is a beautiful theater. It is preferable to attend to an event, or opera ...there are always good options.
A very beautiful theater, we didn't have the chance to make the guided tour, but the little walk we could make gave us a view of how beautiful theater it is.
I always prefer attending an event vs taking a tour of the theater, so we attended an evening of Jazz event that was very fun.

Very famous theater almost in front of Plaza Independencia. Use one of the many websites selling tickets for the theater, but check the prices in advance in order to know if someone is ripping you off.

A must visit if you come to Montevideo. Make sure you attend a concert or play. If you speak Spanish, I recommend Comedia Nacional (the state theatrical company) performances. Not only they are of very high quality, but the prices are very cheap, what Uruguayans call "precios
Nice place to visit and a opportunity to have an overview of the History of Montevideo, as most of the Opera Houses build in South America they are a replica of the European ones
Very old theatre lovingly restored. The tour cost just 60 Paesos & was well worth it. I had pleasant Law student all to myself & she was great. Beautiful theatre built by Freemasons in 1830?

The Solis theatre in Montevideo is well worth a visit. The building dates from 1856 and was renovated in the last decade. It reopened 12 years ago after being closed for 7 years due to the works. The building is magnificent and they run guided tours, that last for a little more

This is the most famous theatre of Uruguay, and all the best spectacles had used to come to sing or dance here, it has been reopened a few years ago. It´s a historic building, and it´s one thing that the visitor has to do
An awesome place to visit. Beautiful design & very good tourist guide. Great concerts, plays, etc Unmissable if you come to Montevideo!
Very nice and classy theatre. Fully renovated a few years ago. Accistic is amazing. It is worth while visiting
Since its restauration, the place is amazing. It's got guided tours and excellent performances are shown there as well. A must for any tourist in the city.

Unfortunately the city was occupied by a graduation ceremony when we visited so we didn't have a chance to see inside. Otherwise the architecture is pretty impressive. Located a few meters from Plaza Independencia so very easily accessed from the city centre

A very nice, classic, building, near the "Old City" ("Ciudad Vieja"), just in front of the large "Independence Square" ("Plaza Independencia"). It was originally just an opera house, but now it was restored, and all kind of events are shown, though theatre and music are the

It is a very interesting, small theatre. It has just been restored. Of course it is not as impressive as Teatro Colon from Buenos Aires, but the sound and design are very nice. My sister is a Opera fan and she goes to the Met all the time and she was pleased with this theatre.
History . history. Really made very good restauration.is at the old town and you have good places near to visit. At night take care with values if you are tourist
Uruguayans love theater, and it shows. I saw three plays during my stay, and all were wonderful! The theatre is very beautiful, and you can purchase tickets on site!

It made me reminisce my youth, attending plays of famous authors and actors. Special mention for the traditional "Carnaval", dancing the nights away until dawn...

If you are visiting Montevideo, this is a place you can´t miss. It is a very nice, historical remodelled theatre. There is a wide variety of options to see, for all sorts of taste and age. You can see opera, classical music, and dance to modern music, black theatre, comedy,
The Theatre is a grand old building rich in the history of the country . The tours are in several languages and very interesting . Its worth your time !

It's the best Theatre in Montevideo. Good Plays, Opera and Singers have been there! It has wonderful accustic and architecture with luxury furnitures, lights and rugs. You may visit only or choose a play to see and also visit the Theatre.

You cannot miss this historical theater, recently renewed has all its magic back! If you can assist to any show it will be a great experience, but if time doesn't allow you, you can take a guided tour to learn about this amazing place. There is a gift shop and nice and fancy

I went on a tour of the Theatre and it was very interesting. The students who take you on the tour are very knowledgeable and love to practise their English. The Chandeliers are amazing as is all the beautiful wood and marble. I was sad that I could not catch a performance here.

If you want to see the first theatre in Uruguay you should go there,it's an amazing building where you can go and learn about uruguayan culture and also see some good shows,nacional and international. There is a gift shop and it's located in Ciudad Vieja,where you can go for a

Historical and amazing theatre in the heart of Montevideo. You basically can't leave the city and say you visited without at least make an outside visit. FYI, the sound design is one of the best in America.

Located on the edge of Plaza Independencia (Ciudad Vieja), we walked past it most evenings on our stay. It attracts a lot of locals to their shows in the evenings. We only paid the gift shop a visit as it was recommended to us. it has some really nice pictures and posters from

We drove by and did not stop.... I asked the driver and guide if we could stop for 5 minutes and look closer.... we did.... and got an earful of history from one of the workers who came out!!! Just stunningly beautiful!!!!! Reminds me of Buenos Aries!!

An iconic must while you are in Montevideo! The City’s municipal theatre –named after Solís, the first navigator to land in Uruguay-- was built by private funds in 1856 and refurbished in 2004. Guided visits allow a good view of its elegant neoclassic architecture. But you

The day we went they were having a strike and the tours weren't running. They still allowed us to see the auditorium and a guy gave us a history of the place. The friendliness of the staff alone is worth 5 stars.

Interesting tour, friendly, amusing and articulate multilingual guides ... we got the free tour which was exceptionally good value.

This is one tour I would certainly recommend. Our guide Florencia, speaking very good english, was quite knowledgeable and funny at the right time. The tour itself was interjected by several short and very enjoyable performances. And the theater itself of course, is a beautiful
The tour was free and took us to many rooms inside the theatre, telling the history and caracteristics.
Again the string Italian influence is here. The facade us like many seen Jan Rome. You can only imagine what it's like for concert. Short walk from pier
This place was just wonderful to see and the guided tour was really good. This theatre was just an amazing place to see.
Just gorgeous. Do not skip the tour. Its well worth to learn about its history and learn about the structure.

It is worth a visit to Teatro Solis both inside and outside which has recently been renovated and reacquired its old days splendor. Inside with it red velvet drapes it resembles a bit the Teatro Scala of Milan. There are guided tours inside in several languages.

We enjoyed the tour of the theatre - it was informative and a good insight into Uruguayan culture. Our guide spoke excellent English and actors also interrupted the tour with little performances which seemed to really entertain the children, overall I would recommend.
This historical and modern building is a fine example of both 18 century and modern architectural fusion .Full of history ,tour of the building is available.
I went with some friends from singapur. We really enjoyed the english tour and were able to see 18th century and modern arquitecture in the same building. Great place to go.
Majestic theatre with great history. onsite restaurant is available for relaxing. One of the tourist sites that is accessible during the city walking tour.

Arrived thinking ummm this isn't what I have read, a lady approached asked if English, then took us on an amazing tour. The history and pride is clear to see. A definite must, free tours on Wednesdays. Actors would appear and act little sketches they were so funny. The cafe is

The tour guides are informative and the facility is world class. Try to take the special tour on the symbolism in the theatre's decor. Pricing for live performances is set with ALL the population in mind. Excellent food in the on-site eateries.

The theatre shows part of the history of the city, and the fact that there are actors around you in the morning tours in the tour adds up! There are different tours every day, 11, 12 am, 4 & 5 pm. English or Spanish. (60$) also an App for virtual tour. The building is

Don't think it is expensive to get in but on a Wednesday you get in for free so that was a bargain. We were shown around the theatre by a charming girl with excellent English and a lovely manner. Every now and then a couple of actors appeared and did a little comedy sketch
Beautiful place! They offer tours in different languages and the price is very good. The place is wonderful and full of history. It's near everything and worth the visit.

We visited this Theatre on Wednesday and it was free on that day. Not sure if it is free every Wednesday. Most fees here in Uruguay are very cheap so I would not worry to much. We had two young guides who where very friendly and where excellent guides. They explained everything
Took a last minute tour here. My Spanish isn't great but it was cheaper so I went for it. Fabulous space (though doesn't touch its counterpart in Buenos Aires) and an eager tour guide.
Unfortunately not when we were there but worth researching if you are coming to Montevideo. Impressive interior and exterior.
Really nice to visit -beautiful theatre -guided tour of 45 mins, UY$ 20/ 40 - check times before ....................
This is a breathtaking building and decorated in a French style ... or so I think. I managed to see a play in Spanish and it was quite an experience

While visiting Montevideo a visit to the teatro Solis is a must. You can take a guided tour ofcourse, but the best thing you can do is visit a concert or a ballet. You will be surprised at the low cost of the performances. They Have a very good coffee shop/restaurant, take

I was lucky to hear a Candombe-Jazz Quartet here one night and it was excellent and very well priced for a last minute ticket -- about $20 for high quality Latin jazz. This theater is gorgeous and the acoustics are great. Caruso and Bernhardt both performed here.
A really good English your, very informative and professional. This was well worth the cost. I loved the fact we got time to take some great photos.
Young passionate people offer inspirational guided tours. Really worth a visit. Try also to book some performances as the theatre is charming and has great repertoire, traditional and contemporary.

What a great cultural experience when visiting Montevideo! You'll feel like you're walking back in time to attend a performance here. Online you can find the scheduled events for the Theatre Solis. They have musical groups, theater shows, ballet, and more. Tickets are very

Teatro Solis is amazing place, some great local history, the tour is worth it, can see who has performed here in it's past plus see some of the costumes that were used in some the past performances. a very opulent Teatro in its day.

This photo is of a former optical shop that is now a book store. This gives you an idea of the past wealth and opulence. The beauty of Montevideo is its tranquility. You get all the culture in a small town chill envoirnment.

It was the first time I have been inside the theatre since it was renovated and I must say I was amazed. The theatre is magnificent inside, it has a very nice café (only order the Tea Complete if you are really hungry, it is a lot of food) and the staff is. Dry, very friendly.

The theater is very beautiful by itself, and the tour makes the visit all the more interesting. It worth the price, both for being instructive about the theatre's history and also for the artistic performances during the tour. You can also learn some interesting local history

Tickets were $200 pesos for two people...less than $10 (us). The conductor was entertaining as ever and truly a national treasure Theater is gorgeous!!!! Seats are uncomfortable on the 4th floor if you sit along side the balcony. Keep in mind this is part of the experience. Go
The theater is big enough to fit some people and is very beautiful. Go there for free tours, you can even choose the language. It's a very nice sight.

A lovely tour. The building and theatre had an amazing history and our guide was very knowledgable about not only the history of the theatre but Uruguay in general.
Very nice place and programs. The theatre was refurbished some years ago, bringing out to light the old splendor of such a place. Also very good place for eating, but expensive. My experience: 10/10!
The Theatre Solis is a pretty building. A good architecture. The inside is also well designed. If you have time go inside.

Very professional guides for the guided tour, in English, Spanish and Portuguese. Beautiful place, full of history and allowing affordable acces to different public target and activities. Worth visit while in Montevideo.

Check for the guided tour times, but even better if you can watch some performance in the evening ... and indulge yourself with a nice dinner at its main restaurant, Rara Avis! Book it first! The "combo" worths a 5 out of 5!!!!
Free tour of the theater on Wednesdays at 4pm! Make time to stop by for the tour, try to see a play...

Teatro Solis is one of the classic theatre's of South Amerca in days gone by. Extremely well restored.

We went there just to take a look and found out there would be a free concert. It was worth the waiting! Great quality music - Clara and Thierry - and organized and courteous staff. The building is also very pretty and well maintained.
This is lovely building to visit, but unfortunately the nearby area is quite dangerous particularly the main square at night. So try covering bag and purses and try to go in a group.

It's a must see when visiting Montevideo. Amazing architecture very well preserved. One of the most important pieces of art and history in Montevideo. It also has a small nice cafe. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable. Just be aware it closes at 4PM.
Lovely architecture. Lovely gift shop and cafe! Worth a stop and across the street from a lovely cobblestone road with great cafe's
Big theater, the history of the place its very nice. Take the guided trip inside, that can be taken in many languages. Takes around 40 min.
The theatre is very beautiful from outside. There are guided tours that take 40 minutes at 11 am and 16 pm.

Montevideo is a beautiful, not very preserved, city. I had only one day to enjoy the town and was very excited to see the theatre. Although staff informed there would be a tour at 4pm ( it was like 3:50pm), when I went to buy the tickets I was informed the tour was cancelled.
I just got in this place for a quick visit, but it worth it avery minute. Beautiful Theatre. Even the cafe' is a pleasant place with a little corner that sells design stuff and books.

The Teatro (Theatre) Solis was a landmark that I couldn't miss during my three week stay in Ciudad Vieja Montevideo. It is located opposite of Plaza Independencia. They have classical concerts, plays, musicals. They also offer a Saturday Afternoon Tango sessions for free with

The theater is centrally located modern and with great acoustics. This theater host plays, concerts and performances. Although it ook modern on the outside it is quite impressive in the inside since it has alot of wood trimming and comfortable seating.
We were in a concert in this theater, the acoustic is fantastic, the place is very comfortable and it's one of the oldest theater of Uruguay

The Solis Theater is the most important theater in town, recently renovated, it hosts plays , concerts and performances the whole year round. In the premises you will also find an excellent restaurant Rara Avis, and a nice coffee shop.

By all means sign up for the guided tour, to learn the rich history of this beautiful cultural center of Montevideo and Uruguay. It's worth it to pay a bit more if you aren't fluent in Spanish--tours are also offered in Portuguese and English.

Very beautiful restored building. Guides are very professional and tickets are cheap, really cheap. It takes one hour but every minute was fun and you learned a lot of extras.

The Night in Vienna performance by the Philharmonic on the 26th was wonderful, uplifting and a respite from the warm summer day. All seats were only 150 Uruguayan Pesos and the performance was completely sold out. The whole experience transported you to a different era. Just

Yes, it is impressive. Extremely beautiful also. The guided tour is very cheap and guides were very attentive. Recommended.

The visit was enhanced by the performance of 3 actor-singers who popped up in the main entrance the theater and in the modern theater. I loved our guides and the anecdotes . It is a contrast to the theater in Buenos Aires which is more regal

August is their winter and on Friday afternoons there is a tango milonga in the large conference room. A wonderful experience, young and old dancers. Great music. Saturday afternoon they do it all over again on the terrace outside. There are two restaurants one is a café and

This place is stunning!! I was fortunate enough to be in montevideo when there was an opera here. Wow it was stunning, the acoustics were impressive as well as the striking architecture all added to a beautiful evening with the wife. Also I did the tour and it's well worth it.

We booked for an orchestral concert at the last minute. Few seats were left but we were fortunate in finding better seats where the audience members hadn't turned up. Recommend anyone to try and see something here and enjoy the atmosphere.

Teatro Solis is a unique music hall. It is not an enormous but everywhere tou go is adequate. The restaurant and the bar are interesting. The shop could be better. The sound is really good and the local Orchestra knows what to do on the stage.

The Solis is indeed a gem, beautiful inside and out. But do try and see a performance when the place really comes alive. I bought a 'restricted view' seat to see the brilliant Moscow Soloists. To my surprise I had a perfect view of the full stage and had a superb evening. The

We went to listen to a concert from the Montevideo orchestra's anniversary. Beautiful theater and great quality of the concert.
We took the guided tour wich was very interesting. It's a beautiful place to visit. They speak at least spanish, portuguese and english. Actors play some scenes during the tour.

Occupying a Prominent corner of the square/plaza this building with its fantastic architecture rests.Inside it is equally beautiful , maybe dramatic ! ! ! If you can see a performance while you are here you wont regret the experience.

My mom and I stopped in for a tour of Teatro Solis on a trip we took to Montevideo last year. I wish I had written this review sooner! The theater is absolutely beautiful, and the visit was made better by the tour we took. Teatro Solis offers tours in many languages, but unlike

If you're on a cultural tour of Montevideo, Teatro Solis is a must even if you only have 20-30 minutes. The tour is only $2 and the theatre is an architectural treasure. Nightly shows also very affordable. Check website ahead of time as they don't let you tour during rehearsals.

Me and my wife went to see the theater around 13:00. We were informed that on Tuesdays the your runs around 16:00. 15 min prior that we arrived there, after ask 3 different staffs finally they set up a meeting point. Around 16:05 my wife ask the counter girl about the tour, she

The tour of Teatro Solis is worthwhile as you will not only get to see the facility but also get a narration of the history and significance of the theater. For $40 URS (just under $2 USD) each person for tours in English, it is worth the time and money. Our family of five

If you're by Montevideo, check the program of Teatro Solis. COmdy, Drama, Opera, Concerts, you call it. Prices are afordable (i.e. not like the Met), so you can get a nice private balcony. They have shows mostly everyday, with great professional performers from the National
we were on a guided trip in this town, it almost felt like there was nit enough sites to fill the day so we were taken here...never did feel the need to get my camera out.

Guided tours are offered in Spanish or Portuguese, cost UYU 20 (USD 1) and are 30min in length. Covers the exterior, the auditorium and a smaller stage. While the tour was good and had ample time to take photos, the building itself is relatively small, so there wasn't as much to
A classic opera theater, completely renewed. A jewell in town not to miss! If you like opera, ballet or concerts, check for the actual,programming upon arrival. Tickets are easily sold out.

The Teatro Solis is a richly decorated theater in downtown Montevideo. It lacks the grandeur and magnificence of the Teatro Colon in Buenos Aires, but the tour guides make up for this by being upbeat and charming. Visits are free on Wednesdays.

We did the guided tour and it was amazing. I strongly recommend. I did the tour in Portuguese but they have Spanish (of course) and English available. You can do the Tour and go for lunch at the Mercado.
Do this on Sunday, when the town is quite and dead. Very low cost. All languages given tours. 1 hour. Take your instrument if you can, maybe your guide will allow you to play a few tunes.
This theater is an amazing arquitectural construction! You can enjoy music and theater! don´t miss a opportunity to enjoy cultural events at Teatro Solis!
the setting is very formal, but the food selection and wine selection very good. Also the silverware is real silver. loved it

We decided to see The Visit. The Theater is beautifully done and a good sample of Art Deco. the tickets are inexpensive (US$8 each). The company was excellent in a Very funny production. We have a wonderful time. People are very polite. If you speak Spanish this is a must
We did the spanish guided visit on a Saturday, mr Santiago Casada guided us and it was great. There was some small plays being done through the visit and was a nice experience. Really recomend.
Had the opportunity to see the wonderful production of The Visit and was impressed by the play and the gorgeous interior of this beautiful theater.

Went to Teatro Solis to see a play from Bertolt Brecht with my girlfriend and was beatiful. The teather is well conserved, including pre-war original Baccarat's chandelier, really impressive. They offer guided tours, and if I remember well, wednesday they are free. If you are
A classical theatre with a beautiful archtecture. Check if there's something going on there while you're at Montevideo. It's worth it.

text.wiki:
Fortaleza del Cerro, also known as Fortaleza General Artigas, is a fortress situated in Montevideo, Uruguay overlooking the Bay of Montevideo. It belongs to the barrio of Casabó, at the west of Villa del Cerro. It holds a dominant position on the highest hill of the department of Montevideo (popularly known as Cerro de Montevideo with its altitude of 134 meters above sea level the sea, on the opposite side of the bay. Its function was to defend the population of Montevideo and its port, on the río de la Plata. Governor Francisco Javier de Elío ordered construction in 1809 and it was completed in 1839; this was the last Spanish fort built in Uruguay. It has housed the Military Museum since 1916.


== History ==


== Monument and Sight ==
It has been a National Monument since 1931 and has housed a military museum since 1916. Today it is a well-known attraction for tourists visiting Montevideo.
