text.quote: Private museum with exhibits about the 1972 Andes plane crash & tributes to its victims & survivors.
trip: I unfortunately didn't get to spend as much time at this museum as I would have liked to but I enjoyed the brief time that I did have there. The exhibits were very interesting and the whole place worked well as both an educational facility and a memorial to the victims and

Was there when they opened at 10 AM. Spent about 2 hours here. Bought ticket at counter-cash only and no credit cards taken. Admission was equivalent to $8 USD. I was very interested in going to this museum as I remembered when this happened. Extremely interesting museum with

We discovered the museum on a walking tour of Montevideo. The exquisite display detailing the trials and tribulations of the team were very informative well displayed plus the insights of the owner made a brief excursion into a lengthy and informative visit. The owner

We frankly didn't anticipate as many crash site artifacts as we saw. Expected the normal story boards, of which there were plenty, but the real highlight here were the many articles recovered from the crash site.

As someone not from the area, I had heard about the the Andes crash but didn't know very much about it. This museum has a really good selection of objects that were used during that time and brought back after the crash but also new items that were discovered at the site very
The museum was very informative. Having seen the movie Alive, it was a real eye opener to see the story from this perspective. I cannot imagine enduring such a tragic event.

Who ever goes to a museum where the curator wanders about and offers insightful info? We quite enjoyed our two hour visit to relive one of the great miracles of the last 50 years. I especially enjoyed that this in not your typical museum of history or art in general, but

This is a must see destination in Montevideo. Starting with the short film clip describing the rugby team plane crash through the amazing rescue of some of the players after 72 days of suffering in the extreme cold. Give yourself more time than you would expect to get to know

This little museum is a Montevideo do-not-miss, that documents in detail the moving drama of the 1972 mishap that caught the attention of the world. It's a uniquely Uruguayan as well as a universally human story. Worth your visit.
Excellent information and artifacts. The movie shown was very good. Excellent if you are familiar with the accident. A lot to take in.
This is a thoughtful memorial to those who died and a celebration of those who survived. Also known as Museo Andes 1972 and Andes Crash Memorial.
Nicely curated exibit. Easy in town location. In an historic building with creaky floors. Very nice and helpful staff. Makes me want to read the book again.
If you are visiting Montevideo you must stop in and see this museum of the airline crash in the Andes .Based on the documentary " Alive " .Very well done !

I had forgotten about this story . A compelling recount of those that died and those that survived. Brilliantly put together. How did these survivors make it off the mountain, this museum will never be able to explain this . Miracles do happen. I was impressed by how much

Today, after five years, I made a return visit to the Andes Museum. I was impressed by how much it had changed and improved: more videos, more photos, more artifacts from the survivors. And clearer explanations (in English and Spanish) of how and where the plane crashed, how the

This museum, which displays the strength and courage of the human soul, will leave you speechless and force you realize how fragile life really is. An inspiring story of survival. We have seen the movie "Alive" read the book, and now have been to this outstanding museum which

Easily overlooked in the hustle and bustle of Montevideo, this place is definitely worth a visit. Extremely comprehensive and thorough, this museum covers both the human side and scientific side of the plane crash in 1972 where survivors eventually emerged after 72 days. I
A moving tribute to human spirit. Very humbling and inspiring. An informative video and many photos and artifacts add to the story.

This museum tells a story of how a team of young men most of who were just 20 came together to survive 72 days in extreme conditions in the high Andes. Having come from Uruguay, they had never experienced harsh weather before. We had the unique opportunity to meet one of the

This little museum had the greatest impact by far of all the things we did over 5 days in Uruguay. I vaguely remembered the story of the crash which came sharply into focus with the movies, artifacts, timelines and stories in the museum. The owner is a personal friend of some of

Very informative. Definitely made you experiance what they went through. Met the owner of the museum which he was giving explanations of the items and the crash. He spoke different languages so that was very helpful. The staff was very friendly and helpful when asked about

We visited the museum...it was a bit hard to find but worth the effort...if you know of this 1972 tragedy you will find extensive artifacts, a film and many descriptions of the events. The proprietor was helpful and gave us additional information regarding these events. The

This place is phenomenal. I highly recommend it. It tells the story of a horrible tragedy perfectly. Lots of english for those who don't speak spanish. Must visit in Montevideo. Thanks for putting this collection together. Mike - Canada

I've been to 7 South American countries, and many of the museums in them, but this by far the most moving I've ever encountered. We intended to stay for just 30 minutes but Jorge, the founder, so beautifully brought the story to life for us (as did the film and numerous English

This has been one of the highlights of my trip! It’s an amazing museum- so personal, very thoughtfully presented, and an absolutely fascinating story. There’s some very moving original pieces [in particular, the red shoe they carried on the expedition got me!] and insightful

Really interesting and informative museum. Knew the story already from reading the book but learned so much more. The letters some of the members wrote to loved ones before they passed are incredibly moving. The founder does a great job explaining things and is clearly
Housed in Old Town Montevideo, the museum is small but full of memorabilia and videos of the events that this rugby team endured after their plane crash, quite moving and quite well put together.

We visited on a very rainy Saturday and were welcomed by the owner in perfect English. There is a video about the crash and how the survivors survived and eventually managed to get help and were rescued. There is loads to read and see and everything is in English as well as

This museum will move you to tears whether you remember the horrific Andes crash of 1972 and the miracle of the survivors. It is filled with artifacts and a haunting video of the survivors as they tell you all they had to endure.

The Andes Museum was a great experience. Get ready for a lot of reading. The reading is worthwhile as are the photos and objects and film about the amazing story of the crash in the Andes of the plane carrying the Uruguayan rugby team. The story is told with sensitivity and

The museum is a great honour to the 29 who perished and a lesson to us all that life is not a gift but should be deserved. With its combination of storytelling, science and insight into the human spirit it has something for everybody. This is one of the best curated museums I

We came across this museum online when googling what to do in Montevideo and I’m so glad we did! It was definitely the highlight of the couple of days I spent in Montevideo. It’s not a huge museum, 3 floors but each floor is quite small. It was really moving and interesting,

An amazing museum in Montevideo! Not only does it pay tribute to those who perished and survived the Andes tragedy but it is a touching tribute to the human spirit! It’s resilience, values and perseverance. A must visit when you are in Montevideo. A special thanks to Director

This is a must see museum. Three floors painstakingly and lovingly detail the events of the tragic 1972 Andes plane crash. Allow yourself at least 2 hours to see all the exhibits, photos, and videos. Note that they accept only cash so be sure to have Uruguayan pesos on you to

We learnt so much & not just about the crash but so much about human endeavour, bravery & positivity despite the horrendous situation these people found themselves in. Totally inspiring. Thoroughly recommend this well put together museum, you will need more than an hour.
Admission was $8 USD, I think... more than other bigger museums. But the visceral experience from seeing the exhibition made it well worthwhile. I left both haunted and amazed.

I came across this museum on TripAdvisor while looking for a warm, indoor activity on a cold day. Had it not been for the other great reviews, I probably never would have stopped by. The admission is a bit more than many other museums in Montevideo, ad it looks small when you

We Did not know what to expect from a Museum created on the concept/ wings of a very tragic accident. We were very pleasantly surprised at the very tastefully done yet impactful and informative museum. We Spent quite a long time reading a lot of information, well curated
Really good small museum to visit in Montevideo. If it is cold weather take a pullover as there is not much heating inside.

Spend some time at this museum which has been lovingly put together to memorialize the Andes airplane crash of young Uruguayan rugby players, several decades ago. Those who survived, spent several months in the snowy mountains with only a part of the fuselage as a refuge. Even

In a quiet street of Ciudad Vieja you’re gonna find the Museum’s building. Ring the bell if it’s not open. We were kindly received by the director and curator Jörg P. A. Thomsen, who explained how the Museum works. The unfortunate plane accident and following days are very well
This is a beautifully sensitive museum that provides insight and detailed information about this tragic story.

This museum commemorates the struggles and decisions of the Uruguayan Rugby team after their plane crashed in the high Andes. I expected the museum to be a little morbid, but it was not at all. It was a chronicling of a group of people in an impossible situation, and how they

Really enjoyed my visit here, we watched a 15 minute overview first in English which was very informative. The rest of the museum is in Spanish & English and really good. Highly recommend a visit.

Highly recommend going to this museum while you are in the city , it’s available in multi languages and Jorg the curator is incredibly nice and friendly and gives additional insight into the accident. It is really well laid out and kept in immaculate shape with lots of memories

A really interesting museum in which I spent over an hour. It’s more than than just the story of a plane crash, it’s about the spirit of survival and resilience. There are a few videos to watch and artefacts and memoirs plus a day to day calendar of events of the 72 days the

Great museum about a though subject. However, it explains perfectly the accident, with a lot of information and even goes beyond by giving some scientific facts. Perfectly describes a true miracle. Would recommend a 100%!
This exhibit is sensitively done well and very moving. This Uruguyan survival story really showed off the values of teamwork and solidarity.

During the visit to the museum you can not just learn something about the tragic accident in the Andes. You also get to know the scientific facts, how it was possible to survive and more about the place in the mountains. What surprised me most were the uncountable incidences of

Over the years I have read several books about the rugby team that was stranded high in the Andes after their plane crashed. While many people on the plane died the story of the courage and ingenuity of the survivors is very inspiring. The museum is well laid out and well
This is just a very well done and extremely interesting museum. The person there that gave a talk (i.e. about a 15 minute lecture) was fantastic.
Very enlightening, Jorge did a fantastic job! He was very informative, friendly and attentive. Highly recommend this museum in the heart of the old town, make a day of it and get sum lunch.

Possibly one of the most interesting and informative museums we've been to. Tells the story of the 1972 plane crash in the Andes mountains in which 16 people miraculously survived. Their personal insight and experiences are shared in an emotive and incredibly interesting

I saw the film, but did not really realise the whole true story behind. It’s great to learn about it first hand and it leaves you with a lesson or two. Also, the museum curator is super friendly and ready to answer all kinds of questions. Besides, he personally knows the

We visited the museum in late March of 2019. What a gem! The museum details the story of the 1972 Uruguayan rugby teams failed flight and subsequent struggle to survive. I was familiar with the story, but this museum really illustrates it in good detail. As an english speaker, I

So much great information about a tragedy you are fairly sure that you've heard about. Starts with a short film, then move onto more and more info about tragedy and lives that followed. If you don't read Spanish just use your google translate, take a pic, and read away.

It's really worth a visit to this well set up museum. Although it is a small space, it took me over an hour to explore as there are so many interesting exhibits and pieces of information to take in- the extraordinary bits of bad luck that led to the crash and the even more
A nice display of photos, news paper reports & Items recovered from the crash site. The question has to come to mind: What would I have done if I was a survivor? Reasonable cost of ARS250.

This is a private museum and there is a U$250.00 fee to enter. It is well worth it. There is so much information on the crash and survivors. The staff does speak English and all the signs are in Spanish and English. The videos are in English or subtitled. A must see if in the
This museum allows visitors to learn why the crash happened, about the people who died, and those who survived. Very balanced story of heartbreak, loss and survival against all odds.

Nice museum with great signage for English and Spanish speakers. Good mix of artifacts and replicas to tell the story. Great introductory video.

You have to visit Museo Andes 1972 - even if you have only a brief time for sightseeing in Montevideo. It is a professionally designed and managed museum covering the tragic flight accident in minute detail. The exhibition draws you emotionally into the event and back to 1972.
This is one of the most informative museums I've ever seen. It has so much information and exhibits from the 1972 plane crash of the Uruguayan rugby team that inspired the book and film "Alive!".

This museum should definitely be ranked as one of the top things to do in Montevideo. Especially for those with no prior knowledge of the plane crash, this museum was fascinating! I had seen the movie ages ago, but this museum has a lot of interesting details I hadn’t know
Excellent presentation of an extraordinary tragedy and miracle. Great staff too - inviting and warm. Highly recommended.

The museum was a moving and dignified tribute to the survivors of the plane crash. It focused on the determination, ingenuity, and will to survive of the survivors. It also highlighted how it gave the survivors a greater appreciation for every day of life. A truly uplifting and

I have to say that the founder Jorg, has done a tremendous job with minimal help from the authorities. It is built on a profound interest in reconciling the interests of survivors, non survivors and their families, and anyone with an interest in this extraordinary story.
In memory of the 1972 Andes air crash. Very powerful and emotional. Probably the best museum in Montevideo.

After seeing the movie and knowing the store behind this amazing survival of people of the crash in very extreme weather conditions, this museum gives you more depth and corrects some facts of how everything happened. I would recommend visiting if in Montevideo.

I had never heard about the place crash before and the story was very moving. Nice museum with a great collection of items retrieved from the mountains.

Even if you havent heard of the tragedy or miracle of the Andes, it is still worth it to visit this museum. The owner of the museum and a man that personally knows the survivors was there, explaining some things and giving incredible insight into the pieces at th museum. It is
This goes into great detail about the 1972 crash and about the people involved. It was very moving and informative.

I traveled to Uruguay with my daughter and she became obsessed with the Andes tragedy. We visited the museum and we were wonderfully surprised. The museum is small, but it is a great tribute to the victims and survivors.

This museum is rightly placed near the top of Montevideo's attractions. It tells a story of survival that everyone seems to know a little about, but it adds a lot of interesting detail and background. They also have a number of exhibits taken from the plane crash as well as two

Learn about the fateful flight of the Uruguayan team whose plane crashed in the Andes and how the survivors struggled to survive over 2 months in the Chilean winter unprotected in the mountains, before being rescued. Sobering and intense.
Lots of artifacts, pictures and history of immigrants of various background coming to Uruguay throughout the years. Entrance is free.
A complete collections of information, debris and survivors belongings on displays. A short documentary movie regarding the incidence.
The small museum is filled with many artifacts and the story is told clearly in several languages. The staff speak many languages are extremely helpful and informative.

My wife and I weren’t sure about visiting this museum. We were in Montevideo and had a spare couple of hours. We ummed and aahed and decided we would. It was the best thing we did here. An astonishingly good museum with a powerful story that is very well told. Don’t do the

A video introduction, followed by information, displays , thoughts of the survivors of the crash all presented in a sensitive and thoughtful way. Information was in Spanish and English.

We only went as we were not finding lots to do in Montevideo, and had heard this was a "must see". Tiny place, but well done and really interesting, even if you don't have any particular interest in the accident...so that says how well done it is. Find an hour and go...it may

Visited this museum wow the story is amazing but the museum is wow so well put together and so much information. From the video at the start and the stories and letters to pieces and photos information in English and a must see would recommend to anyone amazing

This is a very personal museum, founded and run by the friend of one of the men who survived the crash in the Andes in 1972. You may be lucky enough to get Jörg as your guide, as we did. A gripping story is powerfully told.

This museum enthralled me, I found it very moving and thought provoking. The owner was happy to accompany a small group of visitors and add his insights (in Spanish) to this story of human spirit and survival. I would go back to this museum as I am sure I missed a lot first time.

Not sure why this isn't rated one of the top 3 things to do in Montevideo?? Museum is small but the presentation of the story/ordeal, and preservation of artifacts is spellbinding! Very honoring to the both the deceased as well as the survivors. A small/hidden gem MOST

For those who are interested in the miracle of the Andes is an excellent program in Montevideo! Very interesting and touching!

I dimly remember the actual event explored in this museum. We have been on a very short break in Montevideo and chose this museum to visit in our final afternoon thinking we might fit in another activity before everything shut for the day. However we spent more time than

I wasn't sure what to expect when I went to this small but well organized museum in Montevideo's Ciudad Vieja. I ended up spending two hours here, got to chat with the interesting owner of the place (it's a private museum) and was truly gripped by the displays and memorabilia.

"this museum isn't about facts, it's about the experience of people working together to survive" I got that lesson, so I felt the visit was worth the $U ~200/pp. Some of the material was repetitive, so editing would be valuable. However, it is still worth a visit.

I knew only the basics of this extraordinary story, and am happy to report that the experience of visiting the museum opened my eyes to the detailed, awe-inspiring account of 45 brave Uruguayan rugby players and their friends and families. Jorg, who founded the museum, was on

The museum brings together the bigger story behind the tragic event which it is designed to recognize. With a fantastic collection of photos, artifacts, and first hand accounts via videos and letters, what the crash survivors and victims experienced is truly brought to life. It

This was one of our most favourite things in Montevideo - a lovely little place that brilliantly tells an amazing story. We read about in our Lonely Planet book and thought we'd pop in quickly for a half hour or so before going to see something else. Two hours later we left

We really enjoyed our experience. Plan 2-3 hours to really take the time to absorb all the information. The owner is a true gentleman and it was very captivating to listen to all the information he shared with us. You will leave the venue with lots in your mind to think
A great tribute to the passengers of the tragic plane crash into the Andes. A story of pain, desperation, hope and ultimately courage. Definitely worth a visit. Very knowledgeable staff.
The museum does a very nice job of making the experience personal and global at the same time. The exhibit is well researched and respectful to the survivors and their families.

I think this may be the most thought-provoking museum I have ever visited. It does not simply tell the very moving tale of the men and women who suddenly found themselves injured, isolated and freezing after their plane crashed in the winter wilderness of the Andes mountains. It
Very well presented with many photos and details of the events. Needs about an hour or more to go through all the information exposed. Close to other good museums.

Went here with my teenage daughter without knowing much about the story of this accident. Ended up being a highlight of our visit to Montevideo! Extremely interesting, well thought-out, touching museum. To read and hear (in videos) the first hand accounts of the people involved

The most fascinating museum I've ever been in. Keeps one's attention totally with movies and interesting displays. Small space but big on details. Wanted to read every word, and it takes a lot to keep my attention in a museum but the Andes museum sure kept my attention. Would

The museum is an absolute must-see when you are in Montevideo. The museum is dedicated to the 1972 plane crash in the Andes in which members of a Uruguayan football team struggled to survive in an extremely inhospitable environment. If you've read the book or seen the movie

A shattering experience that give so much insight into this amazing true story of tragedy, endurance and humanity. We defy anybody to come out without it having had a profound effect on personal feelings. The museum is well laid out on

text.wiki:
Estadio Centenario is a stadium in the Parque Batlle neighborhood of Montevideo, Uruguay, used primarily for football.  The stadium was built between 1929 and 1930 to host the inaugural 1930 FIFA World Cup, as well as to commemorate the centennial of Uruguay's first constitution.  It is listed by FIFA as one of the football world's classic stadiums. On July 18, 1983, it was declared by FIFA as the only historical monument of World Football, the only building of its kind worldwide.Estadio Centenario is the primary home of the Uruguay national team.  Uruguay has always been a threat when playing in their home stadium, consistently beating top teams. Even the top ranked Brazil national football team has only managed three wins in 20 opportunities; two were official matches during 2010 and 2018 World Cup qualification, but one was Uruguay's heaviest defeat at the stadium, when they lost 4–0 to Brazil in 2009.


== History ==
The construction of the Centenario is one of the most important stages in the development of sports in South America and international football. It was built especially for the organization of the 1930 FIFA World Cup, by immigrant workers in a record time of nine months. Its name originates from the celebration of 100 years of the ratification of the first Constitution of Uruguay.
Initially, all World Cup matches were to be played in the Centenario. However, heavy rains in Montevideo delayed construction of the stadium, so that several matches had to be played in the Pocitos Stadium of Club Atlético Peñarol, and the Parque Central of Club Nacional de Football. It was inaugurated on July 18, 1930, in the match between Uruguay and Peru, with the Celeste gaining victory 1–0, with a goal by Hector "Manco" Castro.

The final match of the inaugural World Cup matched Uruguay and Argentina, with Uruguay winning 4–2. Since then, the Centenario has been the scene of Copa América (1942, 1956, 1967, 1995), three South American Youth Championships (1979, 2003, 2015), a South American Under-17 Football Championship (1999) and 1980 Mundialito.


== Tenants ==

Aside from the Uruguay national team, any football club can rent the stadium for its home matches. Peñarol has done that often, and Nacional rents it for some international matches. Peñarol played all of its home matches at the stadium from 1933 until it moved to Estadio Campeón del Siglo in 2016.
In the case of other Uruguayan teams, they often decide to play there against both Peñarol and Nacional.


== Grandstands ==
The stadium has four Grandstand separated by four lanes. The main one is the Olympic Tribune (and lower Platea known as Olympic), which is named so because the team had won two Olympic championships in a row (1924 and 1928). This has a maximum capacity of 21,648 spectators located in the three rings and the audience. Then there are the "popular", so called because they are sold cheaper, these are: the Colombes, in honor of the Colombes, France in which the national team became Olympic champions 1924 and Amsterdam, because it was where the Celeste were crowned Olympic champions for the second time in 1928.  The Grandstand Colombes accommodates 13,914 spectators while the Amsterdam accommodates 13,923. The  America Tribune is parallel to the  Olympic one. There are also "VIP" boxes and press boxes with room for 1,882 spectators, as well as the platform has room for 2,911 spectators, and additionally the grandstand has room for 5,957 people.Under the Olympic Grandstand are located primary school "Nº 100 Héctor Fígoli"; and the Museum of Uruguayan Football. Under the Colombes Grandstand is located Police Station Nº9.

== 1930 FIFA World Cup ==
Estadio Centenario hosted ten games of the 1930 FIFA World Cup, including the opening and the final matches.
