text.wiki:
Cuisine of Montevideo refers to the food cooked and served in the city of Montevideo, Uruguay. The cuisine served in the city is similar to that consumed in the country as a whole with beef being a staple of the diet and found in a range of foods and torta frita,  a pan-fried cake. However, given the influx of immigrants and tourists into the capital over the decades and centuries, a range of cultural culinary influences can be found in the city.
In recent years the number of restaurants and diversity of cuisine has increased considerably, Lonely Planet describes the Montevideo culinary scene as "just starting to get exciting" with the variety of restaurants springing up in the city from traditional Uruguayan cuisine to Japanese cuisine and Middle Eastern cuisine. Restaurant Arcadia atop the Plaza Victoria on the 25th floor of the Radisson Montevideo Victoria Plaza Hotel is widely regarded to be the finest restaurant in the city.


== Cuisine ==
A torta frita is a pan-fried cake consumed in Montevideo and throughout Uruguay. It is generally circular, with a small cut in the centre for cooking, and is made from wheat flour, yeast, water and sugar or salt. Beef is very important in Uruguayan cuisine and an essential part of many dishes. Many of the restaurants serve beef steaks, pork or chicken dishes. Given that Montevideo is a coastal city, it is also provided by a plentiful supply of fresh fish which alongside beef and chicken is very important in the Montevideo cuisine. Some restaurants like Che Montevideo on the Rambla Gandhi in the Pocitos area of the city on the coast specialize in fresh seafood.


== Mercado del Puerto ==

The centre of traditional Uruguayan food and beverage in Montevideo is the Mercado del Puerto ("Port Market"). This complex contains a considerable range of restaurants and cafes. La Palenque restaurant serves Uruguayan and Spanish cuisine with a variety of lamb, pork and cold meats dishes with vegetables, paella, rice and shellfish. Additionally, the market is host to various cultural events on Saturdays.The Mercado del Puerto is the city's most famous area for parillas ("barbecues"). The open-aired building which houses the market was built in 1868. While originally a venue for fresh produce, it is now filled with parillas. The structure was built in the style of a nineteenth-century British Railway station. It is listed among "The Best Markets" in South America by Frommer's.


== Restaurants ==

Montevideo has a variety of restaurants, from traditional Uruguayan cuisine to Japanese cuisine such as sushi. Western fast-food chains such as McDonald's, and  Burger King are  evident in the city, showing the forces of globalization.
The Restaurante Arcadia, on the 25th floor of the Radisson Montevideo Victoria Plaza Hotel
is considered Montevideo's best restaurant.Arcadia is set in a classic Italian-inspired dining room and serves lavish dishes such as terrine of pheasant marinated in cognac, grilled lamb glazed with mint and garlic, and duck confit on thin strudel pastry with red cabbage.El Fogon is more popular with the late-night diners of the city. Its interior is brightly lit and the walls covered with big mirrors. Officially a barbecue and seafood restaurant, it serves grilled meat dishes, as well as salmon, shrimp and calamari. Also of note is the Cru. Numerous restaurants are located along the Rambla of Montevideo.
Kokoro is a Japanese restaurant located on Viejo Pancho in the barrio of Pocitos. It serves traditional Japanese cuisine, mainly dishes with meat and fish to suit the Uruguayan palette. Its dishes range from appetizers such as a dumpling of salmon and nira, to Sauteed whitefish with Teriyaki sauce and white rice to rolled sushi and sashimi and Japanese curry and rice with Wagyu (beef) or chicken. Deserts include green tea ice cream and apple rolls.Kazbah is Middle Eastern restaurant located on the Bartolomé Mitre. It serves dishes such as falafel, schwarma (doner kebabs), couscous and tagin.Panini's is a notable Italian restaurant located in the Ciudad Vieja historical area of the city, just off the Plaza Independencia, and is testament to the influences of some of the Uruguayan Italian immigrants. It is noted in particular for its "degustación de pastas", described as "a veritable smorgasbord of noodley delights."Also of note is Rara Avis in the east wing of the Solís Theatre, a branch of the Uruguayan chain of restaurants called La Pasiva in the Centro area which serves pastas and meat dishes, and the restaurants in the Mercado del Puerto and the Mercado de la Abundancia.


== Bars and pubs ==

Many of the notable bars in the city are located in the barrio of Pocitos near the sea. Amongst these pubs of note include the "Tibet Pub", "La Estada", "La Vuelta" and the "Rosh Bistró Bar".
Many bars and pubs are located inside community markets. Customers at markets may sit at bars to order sausages, offal, asado, and other meats that are being grilled right in front of them. Meats, especially cheap cuts of beef and pork such as sausages and organs, are a large part of the ordinary diet in Montevideo. The various meats are served with simple side dishes such as crusty bread, tapenades, fried potatoes, and tapas. During lunch, local lager beer is the most common choice of accompaniment, although soft drinks such as colas are widely available. In addition to having bars and pubs, markets in Montevideo also sell fresh produce, mate, coffee, kitchen ware, and other basic consumer goods.

In the old area of the city or the immediate surroundings notable pubs include the "Shannon Irish pub" and "Chains Pub". The Shannon Irish pub in the Old City area of the city was established in 2001. It is located at Bartolomé Mitre 1318, 2 blocks from the Plaza Independencia and 1 block from the Plaza Matriz. Bradt Travel Guides says "An Irish pub on Montevideo's liveliest pub street, with a wide range of beers (although Uruguayans find it hard to understand why an Irish pub doesn't serve Irish coffee)." The pub is an important centre for Irish Uruguayans, often featuring live music. The pub serves traditional Irish whiskey by Jameson (1780), Paddy (1779), Powers Gold Label (1791), Bushmills (1608), Redbreast, Ballantine's (1827) and others and mainly sandwiches and fajitas.


== Former world record barbecue ==
On the 13th of April 2008, twelve thousand five hundred cooks in Montevideo together grilled 12 tonnes (26,500 lb) of beef, setting a new Guinness world record. The event required a grill nearly 1.6 km (1 mi) long and 6 tonnes of charcoal. The barbecue bested the previous record of 8 tonnes, which was set by Mexico in 2006. Montevideo's record held until March 2011, when 13.713 tonnes (30,232 lb) of beef were grilled in General Pico in Argentina.

ARCIA, M. C. (1970). Food habits of a moderate income group of 50 Uruguayan women. Thesis (M.S.)--Pennsylvania State University.
GARCÍA ROBLES, H. (2005). El mantel celeste: historia y recetario de la cocina uruguaya. [Montevideo, Uruguay, Ediciones de la Banda Oriental.}
NÚÑEZ, T. (2008). La cocina uruguaya: orígenes y recetas. Uruguay, Placer, La primera revista uruguay del buen vivir.
WIZO URUGUAY. (1991). Wizo cocina con Herminia. Montevideo, WIZO Uruguay.
M. DE GINERMAN, S. (2002). El sabor de los recuerdos: cocina judía y tradición. Montevideo, Uruguay, Ediciones Trilce.
text.quote: Grand 19th-century market building filled with bustling, meat-centric restaurants & bars.
trip: This area is very close to the port, so if there is a cruise ship in town then it will be busier than usual. There are lots of shops, some nice places for a drink and the food market is what attracts the locals. There are also a few stalls selling local artisan products. Not

This was the only lively place in town as we were here on a Sunday. I was great to wander around the market with stalls on the outside and all the BBQ's on the inside. I was amazing to see all the meat being cooked on the different types of BBQ

We didn't buy anything but rather just watched everyone else shop. The attraction here to my eye is the architecture itself. Fun place to hang around for a bit and immerse yourself in local goings on. With a health helping of tourists!

I am a lover of the market food, especially in Latin America. So we tried this one. Although is near of the port, you don´t feel a marine atmosphere like Santiago Chile Market or Canton. Is Uruguay, and is meat. After had a search in the different store looking souvenirs, we

There on Sunday, so didn't open until 11am. Building is lovely old world architecture, filled with food stalls, shops and restaurants with raw products on display spruiking the delights of their eatery. Lively atmosphere.

A lovely old cobblestones area with vendors and stores. You can negotiate with the vendors if something catches your eye. The usual souvenir stores, plenty of restaurants and loads of benches to rest.

The building is a piece of wonderful old municipal architecture with lots of exposed wrought ironwork internally. Today it functions as a dining venue and contains a selection of bars and restaurants. The fit out is very sympathetic and the space has a pleasant ambience. Sadly,
Very picturesque place to visit. Interesting shops and restaurants. A little pricey at the port, better to walk a little further

This is the first time visiting this market place and the overall experience was average! Several vendors in the area! Some vendors were willing to negotiable the price of various goods. Also various restaurants are in the area as well!
large number of stores and stalls, right in the port area; easily accessed from cruise ships; some good deals available.
Could have spent more time here and really shopped. Lots of fun restaurant choices. Large covered Mercado with many sights and sounds to enjoy
Mercado del puerto is great located in an old building and across from the port you’ll Love it every trip to Montevideo

Great steaks. We were dropped here after a tour of the city. The guide had suggested steak pecante. We found one of a zillion steak houses and set out to try it. We attempted to split a steak but we were not sure if the language barrier had worked against us when we each

If you come to Montevideo you really must visit to Fort market. We had a terrific lunch at La cabaña Veronica. You might consider ordering one of their plates to share because they give you so much meat you might want to share it with someone.

This is a very busy tourist trap area which is especially busy when there’s a cruise ship in port as they are docked right across the street. In the big indoor area there are loads of restaurants all jostling for customers. The place was so noisy it was hard to hear. There was

We really enjoyed wandering around this market while touring the old town. Lots of restaurants and souvenir shops. Very busy when we were there as a cruise ship had arrived and I think the market is their first shore excursion!!
If you are a “foodie”, this is the place to go. We had our first lunch here and it did not disappoint. In fact it was fantastic!

I expected to find a market filled with interesting foods and products. Instead, I managed to endure less than 10 minutes in this small space where there is only one type of food available. The ridiculous amount of asados being prepared fills the space with the stench of animal

People trying to lure tourists into their restaurants as soon as you walk in. I am not sure how was it before Bourdain's show but other comments suggest he popularized it and it has gone downhill since. Ok to visit as concept is interesting but if one steers away from it, it
The place is nice to see and have an idea about it. Inside there is a continuous noise. The prices are very high there.

Mercado del Puerto is located near the coastline of Montevideo and is a great social hub in which to enjoy many great foods and drinks. The market is indoors and hosts a plethora of places to sit and enjoy the quirky atmosphere.

Only wandered through - lots of bbq restaurants. Lots of noise and hustle and bustle. Very busy on a Friday around 3pm. Only really a place to go if you want to eat. But you can see the meat on the bbqs. Not a quiet place if you want peace. Interesting to see but only need
Meat. Bassically Meat. Hot inside. Nice to see, but there are more quite and better places for Lunch. Tourist attraction. But makes part to understand History and Cultura.
Nice experience to have some great meat and spend some time. It wasn't too busy,so we could relax and eat in tranquilidad.

This place is ok to have a quick stop and visit at , but it is very much tourist orientated, I doubt the locals eat here. We went after a walking tour in which our guide had pointed out some other good restaurants which we ate at. It’s in a nice old building and had some shops
A MEAT LOVERS PARADISE. Restaurants galore sporting g beef, beef and more beef. Great location and easy access too. t
But, worth the visit. Mostly places to eat asado (Barbecue). Prices are higher than the rest of town.
We have been a couple of times and we found some souvenirs and good food; we advise to try some empanadas The place is fancy and the price is pretty ok

This place opened in 1868 as the main produce and meat market of the city. Today is is full of restaurants, from fast food to full meals. The structure is made of cast iron. It is fairly close to the city's cruise ship terminal. The hucksters for the restaurants can be a bit

Having arrived from the Buenos Aires San Telmo Mercado our hopes and expectations were high. Sadly we were seriously disappointed, this is basically just a bunch of very expensive Parilla restaurants surrounded by souvenir shops. Go and visit but be aware of the cost if you

It seems like a tourist trap, but as tourists we had a right ( just OK ) meal at El Palenque. A bit agressive were the other places inviting u in. There s a taxi stop nearby that could be helpful if there were taxis!

Once a market this place is now full of restaurants and shops. It is very interesting BUT it closes at 6pm! We walked around it and the smells of bbq meat and fish are amazing. Definitely worth a visit if you are here!

The mercado is worth a visit with many bars, parillas and restuarants if in Montevideo. It was packed to the rafters when I visited on a Saturday. The mercado has quite an ambience with is popular with locals and visitors alike..

The mercado is ever changing but still a must visit for me. Some parillas have closed in lieu of burger bars but that is just evolution. I love burgers also. There are still good parillas and lots of fun to be had even if some of the crowd has relocated
Pretty expensive for food compared to argentina and average service. Not really worthwhile checking out
As you leave renter the cruise port, don’t fail to do into the Mercado to enjoy the tastes, sights, smells. Locals and tourists both come here. Eat at El Palenque! We dream of it even today!
Amazing place with good food. They have a lot of options of restaurants to eat and all of them were packed but totally worth it!

I went there really looking forward to seeing an authentic market with many food stalls selling diferent kinds of Uruguayan foods like cheeses, empanadas, vegetables, etc but what I found was a food court with very overpriced parilla restaurants and a couple of souvenir stores.

It doesn’t look too impressive from outside but once inside; one can find decent souvenir shops and several fancy restaurants. There are couple informal places which many people were eating empanadas. It didn’t t stop there but found a restaurant which had a second level. I

Lots of action on a winter’s Saturday at lunchtime. So much fun to be there! We had a great grilled lunch, bought some trinkets and enjoyed the guitarists and Candombe dancers! Really a must if you visit Montevideo!

Of course, one must visit Palenque, and sit at the counter as close to the grill man as is possible to enjoy the "grilling ballet" and the grill master and the waiters intertwine and graciously avoid collision as the food orders are executed. Please note that the bulk of the

Located in the peripheral area of the harbor de Montevideo and on the border of the old city. The history sad that this building was a railway station for the city of Asunción in Paraguay. A mistake had that it was debarked in the Montevideo harbor and transformed in a popular
See... it is a good place to visit... there are restaurants and shops and this is it. I was expecting a bit more but it was an Ok place to see.

When it is sunny it is better to sit outside and enjoy the sun and the musicians performing. It'w a pitty it is not open after 6 in the evening. We found some souvenirs in good prices but it is mostly for eating. It looked very touristy; not very authentic.
Was once a railway station and now houses shops, restaurants and bars. Real local feel as well as catering for the tourists Well worth a visit

We were there on Good Friday and they had seafood dishes available too, that was a plus. We had lunch at Estancia del Puerto, the food was delicious, freshly prepared and the service was great. The market is fairly big and there are various restaurants with sitting areas. There

A small ancient market in front of main port. it is a nice place to have contact with local food close to downtown Montevideo. Of course, meat is the specialty here. You can enjoy the smell of grilled meat long before arriving in the market. Not as pricy as I expected. Worth the

Formerly a train station, this bustling and energetic market is a one stop shopping place for souvenirs, music, wine and more. You can experience the famous BBQ parrilla where meat is king. Uruguyans take their meat seriously here. Bring your sense of humor to deal with the
Mercado is full of excellent places to eat. Is a lively place especially on weekend afternoons. Though is next to the sea the meat is what shines here

The Mercado del Puerto is a thriving, bustling, fun mixture of restaurants, souvenir shops, stalls and lots of music, especially on the weekends during the afternoon. Most of the people who work there seem to be having a lot of fun (at least they were each time I was there).

This market is worth visiting both for the interesting old iron construction of the building and for the many barbecue restaurants there. It has been called a Disneyland for meat eaters with good reason. Though I do not eat red meat most restaurants serve several barbecue

On our recent visit to Montevideo we visited the mercado del Puerto.it is a good place to have a taste of charcoal meat, characteristic of Uruguay.If you wander around the place you will be approached by many restaurant's waiters trying to persuade you to visit their

Our guide said we were stopping here at the “mall” to use the toilets and have 45 minutes for shopping. The building is an old steel structure that apparently had been a marketplace in earlier days. The inside was nothing like I expected. There were some clothing and souvenir
Awesome little conglomerate of amazing restaurants and street vendors. It was a bit more scale than I expected.
It seems like all the traditional latin america markets with good restaurants, some different products and expensive "regalos". But you might go there

Close -easy walking distance -from the cruise port entrance, this is a riot of sounds and smells, and the sheer choice of eating opportunities is amazing (which is frustrating when all your food and drink is waiting for you on board!). As usual sensible precautions to be taken
Great service especially if you can speak a few words (please and thank you) in Spanish and if you have a sense of humour!

The Market is full of Meat Restaurants and the smell of the Barbecuing draws you into the place. It is bustling and noisy inside as practically every restaurant is busy. It is a great way to sample Uruguayan Culture by just walking around but the smells of the delicious meats
Really great place with some of the best eateries in town. Great atmosphere. A must visit place on your stay in Montevideo. Not Cheap. But the food was brilliant
Close to the waterfront - you can't miss this food-heaven and especially not if you are a meat lover. The best meat in town can be found here. Excellent restaurants.
This place is meant for tourists from cruise ships. Very crowded, expensive and hot. We chose different place (Es Mercat) for lunch and definitely were very happy about our choice.

A place to be visited. Choosing among all offers that option that is most enjoyable for you, you will for sure have a nice lunch, dinner... Could it have become a bit too nosy and not so cosy anymore ?

Amazing place in Port of Montevideo, Awesome food is everywhere around here , and you can choose lots of places. Seafood , anykind of meat is available for most demanding hungry tourist around here. Everything out there is worth of trying. Is a bit pricy, but when you taste

What a disappointment, perhaps my own fault because I had high expectations. A collection of overpriced eateries in a classical market setting that makes you wonder what it must've looked like in its heyday. Glad I've been, but the Mercado Viejo in town has a much better

We had lunch here on two days. The atmosphere is great - it is a very vibrant and colourful place. The meat stalls are amazing and they have great wines too. We were on a RTW trip and this is one of our favourite memories.

This is located just opposite the cruising pier There are beautiful artworks from local,T shirts ,key chains,necklace,and of course soccer souvenirs It is accompanied by restaurants which serve steaks, but we found the buildings are hot to go inside due to the heat,open flame

We enjoyed walking and taking in all the different open cooking restaurants, very different from anything we've seen before on our travels, we enjoyed a drink on the inside only, as the inner part was to hot for us!!!! with all the cooking going on!!!! There's also restraint on

There are so many different places to eat inside and out. All kinds of different things to eat. All serve cold beer. Some speak some English. We have tried 3 different restaurants so far. Well worth taking the time to stop. There are also small stores inside and out.

The Mercado is a go-to location for visitors looking for Uruguayan gifts. Offers several shops and restaurants. You don’t need much time here but if you’re in Montevideo, you’ll definitely want to stop by.

As a nice place to know and get acquainted with the uruguay culture. The building is an old construction close to the wharf/port area that agregates a number of "parrillas" run by each of the restaurants owners. In my opinion the food is ok but not the best you can find in

We had a great parrilla at the Mercardo. It is a hopping old market filled with restaurants, catering to tourists and locals. We sat at the bar of one of the restaurants as we watched the chefs create salads and deserts. We were served perfectly cooked meats and vegetables. I

Having visited other Parrillas in Montevideo, in Colonia del Sacramento and in Buenos Aires; the Parrillas in the Mercado del Puerto seem to only offer a facade of what I imagine once was. Overpriced and overrated food.

I liked this place very much! It is the real heart of Montevideo :). Full of barbecue restaurants, bars, must visit this place when you are in Montevideo. We had very good lunch there, but you must wait little time for free place to sit. :)

It was a great experience to see how they prepare the food in the fire. The restaurants serve lots of meat, but I'm vegetarian and I found lots of vegetarian options too like veggie skiwers, grilled potatoes with Roquefort, empanadas, etc and don't forget the Alfajores for

This place is a homage to meat, there are grills everywhere, meat being roasted and barbecued, but I wanted to take a look at the place because it's such an iconic destination here. The waiter didn't seem to have judged me when I said I was vegetarian and he offered me a variety

Located across from the port this place a great secret lol Anthony Bourdain loves it and it’s a real place. Food, and lots of other things like souvenirs etc. The kids where in awe the adults were fascinated by our local exposure to Uruguayan culture. A must see

If you love to eat meat, this is a must. Uruguayan beef is great and here you can find lots of options. I can recommend especially you to try meat by-products, something not very eaten in other countries but in South America really know how to do it. Give it a try to

This is the place to go for a taste of local culture. All 5 senses will be put to the test as you smell the meat roasting, hear the locals, touch the produce, see the colors, and talk to the people. We had lunch here and the options are endless. Also outside of the market you
Anthony Bourdain called this place "Meatopolis" and he was right. Just lots and lots of meat restaurants all trying to get your business. Pretty amazing.

The smell when you enter - as bbq from heaven. Here you can find a range of different restaurants/parillas which are eager to make a better bbq than the neighbours. Everything is loud, service staff working as fast as they can but if you come exactly at high lunch there will
There is nothing actually from a market, just restaurants, all of them for tourists with high prices for anything you order.

Do you want to: Eat? Check Drink? Check Shop? Check Stroll? Check Relax? Check Do nothing? Check This market and area is just a block from the cruise port and there is something for everyone here. There are street vendors with crafts, plenty of restaurants and stalls with

The meat from the traditionel Uruguayan grill is not to compare with anywhere else in the world (at least where i have been). The prices are alright, the atmosphere is nice and the food is amazing!! A must to visit Mercado del Puerto when visiting Montevideo.

First of all this was not a mercado(market) it is an old market building consisting of various restaurants. Food is excellent. It is really there for tourists and of course people from cruise ships. On whole though it well worth a visit.

If you come to South America thinking about eating good meat, this is the place to go. You will see the typical "parrilla" (grill) and taste good local products in a lively setting. You might even have the chance to listen to some local tango singers or other musicians while

This market is fantastic. Just the right amount of smoke in the air bringing flavor to life. Noisy in a great way and wow is the food delicious. Only open for lunch but you can walk through and scope out where you want to eat in the morning.

Unfortunately closed on the Sunday evening when looking for a meal., however did visit to have a quick look around after friends described it and is a great concept. Lots of outlets with a variety of menus. Smell great from the open fires & cooking. Will definitely eat here on
Excellent place for have a good meals and drinks. Typically Uruguay. You can find meat, seal food, and others kinds. Beers, Wines and everything. You can miss this place!
Just a small, old and closed marketplace full of meat restaurants for tourists... Looks old, feels old... Did not like the place.
Lots of restaurants and gift stores , lots of artesanal and typical stuff. The medio y medio is a very nice typical beverage, you can be carried on.
Absolutely overrated place. Worst service ever in every restaurant. Inflated prices. Shameful to recommend this.
The market is quite touristy, but it has a huge selection of meats and a great vibe. It’s worth checking out for sure!

Awesome ambiance and food variety...well worth it if you like meat, beef, pork, poultry, fish, desserts and drinks....vegetarian available but mostly wood grill ....I love it here. Try Casa de Veronica for a full authentic experience...no economical options at this market.

Mercado del Puerto is a tourist trap, it is kind of a meat temple with parrillas restaurants everywhere, the problem is the price of each meal. The service is horrible and the attendants don’t seem to be very comfortable working at those restaurants. Do not expect a special
There are a lot of restaurants here that offer good food. The prices are a bit higher than other areas though.

During our stay we visited several times to different establishments. Every meal was delicious and freshly cooked with pleasant waiting staff. I read reviews and some stated it was pricey by South American standards but it was worth it. There was a good variety of meat options

The market is host to a number of grill restaurants serving up a variety of grilled meats. It's rightfully been described as a carnivore's paradise! We chose La Chachra to dine and it turned out to be a good choice. The service was excellent and the meats were grilled expertly.
Great places to eat, though. More options such as, with typical fruits and sauces should have been good.
All over in the area you will find restaurants with great food. Prices are also very good and pealsant. Services fine all over

Tipical place in Montevideo, full of history and tradition. You will eat good meat and uruguayan specialities grilled in front of you. You can see how they cook it. Recomend to eat inside the market in one of the little places where you can sit in the bar. I not recomend the
Great place to eat good food and beer. Amazing people and place. I recomend this Place at all. 🙂🙂🙂🙂🙂

While there is much more on offer than meat, it is clearly the star of the show amongst the restaurants vying for your attention in this very old market hall. Wander through the entire building before deciding what appeals to you. I settled on a bar seat at Cabaña Veronica and
Worth a visit even as a tourist. Typical South American grilled meat restaurants where you sit around and watch the meat being cooked. Don’t recommend for vegetarians or in animal rights
Definitely visit the market. There are loads of choices of places to eat. We really enjoyed it. We ate at la palenque which was great. Loved the way the food is cooked.

If you choose to have the most complete barbecue with the best meat in town you may stop by the famous “Mercado del Puerto” ( the “ Harbour Market”) where you will find the most complete restaurants ( more than 25 ) with the most significant offer related to meat High rate

If you want to have a different barbecue, watching the grill close, in a high chair, it probably has some very good meats. As a market it’s a bit disappointing.at least a good alfajor\dulce de leche store close...

Forgot which place exactly I went to eat but I have to say that products are kinda overpriced and not tasting as good as expected. Wines aren’t too expensive tho and staff was always alright and agreed to help us with settling the bill half in cash and half in card as we had to
Allows for a glimpse into the past of the port with the old customs house converted into a covered market with artesanal products and crafts and a few good restaurants. Even locals love it.

The market is exceptional if you want to eat meat. Nevertheless, three people in my family are vegetarians. You can only find meat restaurants and a few gift stores. I would therefore only recommend this place if you intend to have a typical uruguayan barbeque lunch.
This public market is not very big, but have places for many kind of budgets. The main advantage is that is located at the ciudad vieja.

My walking tour ended here and over the years, I have grown wary of tours that frequent anywhere that sells wares. So initially, I was not going to buy anything in here. I spent enough time checking out the artistry of the building and making note of the prices so I could
The Mercado del Puerto is a place with many restaurants. Meat, fish, chicken, all sorts of meals. We had a delicious rib barbecued for us! It worth the time and the money!!!
Excellent place for lunch and enjoy the world cup matches. Food is excellent and very good service. Price is affordable and best Parrilla (grill) of Montevideo

Mercado del Puerto is a cool place to check out and look around. There are stores, merchants, and restaurants. There are lots of things to see, buy, and eat, however its a big tourist trap because it’s near where the cruise ships arrive. It’s overpriced, yes, but definitely do

Visited the Mercado del Puerto in April, the smell of the food being cooked and the atmosphere of the place , not too crowded with people at the time, made this place a must ! The food was excellent and really enjoyed our visit.

Una vez fue y yo pagaba con tarjeta de crédito. Volví dos semanas después con un amigo y el mesero decía que necesitamos pagarle una propina seperada porque el propietario no le daba el dinero para sus servicios. Ya traté de pagar con tarjeta de crédito y no los aceptarían y

The Port Market is well worth a visit as you stroll through the old city in Montevideo. It is full of BBQ eateries, seating inside and out served by different kitchens and BBQs. This is an afternoon lunch place and will close in the evening. During our walking tour we went

Old world charm, excellent dining options, bars, nice little shops, vendors, & carts. Food prices are very reasonable for the quality! Most restaurants there accept credit cards and paying with a foreign credit card will save you 18% on your bill. (VAT refund). Be sure to

We read about it on a blog and wanted to have a look, as we were 2 days in montevideo and wanted to see as much as possible, this was a great start of our South American trip. Never saw that much meat in one place and even more, the way how they prepared it was just incredible.
This one is like any other market in vicinity of cruise terminals. Lots of restaurants, lots of souvenir shops. Not very pricey.

The Mercado del Puerto is riddles with Assado-style eateries which specialize in all kinds of meats - different cuts and even specialities such as blood sausage and offal. Though unusual, I highly recommend that you sample some - they do taste yummy! My favorite was the
Amazing place with great food and wine. Such a great place to go with friends and share the atmosphere that this place brings.

Down town Montevideo, one block from port there is this marvellous market. Full of restaurants and places to have drinks for me it us better to ho st noon. Have a nice interior wakk snd choose a restó. The best ae near the main door. Prices are like New York or Buenos Aires.

If you love meat!! That is tour place to go. Chivito, Asados, pizzas and fruit of the sea are for real the most delicious of this city. Good for families, couples por alone that was muy case. Handcraft, gifts and of course a variety of "Mate" pots
this place is very lively and filled with so many different shops. the place is amazing, food...drinks...full of people offering different types of food. this is a must see place.

Lively, noisy, full of people and food and drink, this place was amazing. So much to see and do, shops to buy local produce or souvenirs, restaurants offering South American style cooked steaks, which is just great to watch as it’s so theatrical. If you have a few hours to

....do not miss it. As everywhere else: lots of local products. Besides seeing a lot of fish or fruit varieties I can't find at market place at home it is always interesting to compare the prices. We did not eat there and I regret it because food is always fresher, more tasteful
You should better see the place and sorroubding old town! Looks a bit poor but nice.lots of homeless and beggars around specially for tourists
This "market" can not be skipped. Great for lunch! Walk around first before deciding where to eat!!!

It's clearly touristy although does get a local crowd and it can be a good place on the weekends, when other parts of Montevideo may be quiet - lots of souvenir stalls, musicians, and then a whole lot of bbq and seafood restaurants and their touts. Check reviews first - the one

The worst steak I have ever eaten. Like a chewing gum! The money doesn't worth the food. They even charge the cover and cutlery! So many more better places in Montevideo for less money! I don't recommend this place at all.

This is a revived market now home to 20 or so parrilla (wood fired barbecues) all competing for the lunch time trade (when we were there). It is touristy because it's close to where the cruise liners dock, and the few pedestrianised streets around are unlike the rest of
Ate here inside at the bar amazing meats and staff friendly I speak Spanish but English is ok not expensive great meat and more meat great service and would recommend to anyone

Full of atmosphere, great to wander around. Terrific smell of cooking food that makes your mouth water. Outside, just up the street there is an old cafe, one of its walls is covered in old "The Beatles" memorabilia, well worth a look if you're a "Beatles" fan.
I you want to enjoy the best barbecue this is the place you have to go. There are several restaurants with different options but beef and chicken meat are the best.

The building is 150 years old, where the customs used to keep the goods. Nowadays it has many places where you can eat the best meat, parrillada, and also seafood, like paella. We use to visit every time we come Emilio's restaurant called L'Amittie. Everything what he cooks is

One of the must stop by for lunch/snack stop. The market is small, but packed with tanalizing food stalls selling theri grilled cuts of meat. Come hungry because the sampler portions are huge! It is an authenic experience that one should not pass, After devouring you rmeat laden

Mercado del puerto is definitely a “must visit” location when visiting Uruguay! You will find lots of great eats, coffee shops, and gift shops with great prices! I had lunch at Don Garcia and had the “chivito” plate! My boyfriend tried the artesian beer! The owners relative is a
The best place in town to taste some amazing “parrilla/asado”. It’s steps away from the the old city and the harbour. You can go have lunch and then go for a stroll at the old city.

The Mercado del Puerto is a MUST GO place. There are lots of little stalls selling art work! The surroundings are nice and full of shops and souvenirs. Inside the market there are wonderful places to eat the famous partilla! It is such a unique experience, that cannot be

I am a meat lover so when I am in Uruguay is like I am in heaven. With that being said, I've tried plenty of food including meat. Mercado del Puerto (like the locals call it) has been by far the best! I came back 3 times, amazing food, fresh and delicious, I also bought some

Situated in the old historic town, a favorite among locals. Large choice of restaurants with open fire kitchens. Eating there is an experience in itself. Watching the meals being cooked over open fires, very tasteful meals indeed and often…at least when we were there, music and

This market is a barbecue heaven. It’s great to wander around watching the chefs cook on the wood fired barbecue pits. You can smell the smoke and BBQ smell 200 metres away but it’s not smokey inside the market. We went there two days in a row- fantastic place to see.

We didn't actually eat here but wished we had as the smells of grilling meat was delicious. Lots of smallish meat restaurants with some souvenir shops scattered in between. Very busy place with lots of tourists. The building itself is an old renovated meat market with iron

This is the most traditional place to eat in Montevideo. It has a lot of restaurants where meat is the highlight, along with dulce de leite desserts. The architecture is also worth seeing. Some restaurants have a mezzanine, I highly recommend because of the view of the market.
Not much variety in choices of food and the items are a bit pricey but it is worth a stop to see what is there. Check the hours as it is only open until dusk.
Most of visitors are tourists but still worth the visit. Good place to buy usual souvenirs and have a good meal if you are meat lover - vegetarians stay away.

Yes, I understand that it is a market specialized in grilled meats and seafood, but the truth is that there is no greater variety of dishes to choose from. Most offer well prepared grilled meats but the prices are very high.

Yes you can get seafood here, or a beer, or buy some souvenirs, but this is the place to explore the Uruguayan love of grilled meat. If you are getting off a cruise ship it is very convenient - just a couple hundred yards up from the exit of the port complex. There are some

Though we didn’t eat here, we did enjoy the atmosphere and taking in the sights. It has a nice vibe to it here but was maybe a little on the touristy side and expensive. It’s a busy place so be prepared for a lot of people!
Good meat (asados) a bit pricey but worth it. Few stores, not cheap at all. In general terms, good attitude towards visitors.

What a fantastic place! Several parrilla restaurants on the same place, the “Mercado del Puerto”. You can see a lot of fire and meet been grilling, ask for the prices and chose the best place to have you meal. It really depends what do you like most, the more sofisticated the

Loved this place! Has a great vibe - lots of barbecue places to choose from most with counter and table seating. I would expect to pay more here than in other places but worth it for the atmosphere. Queue up for an empanada while you are there - they are delicious!!

El Mercado del Puerto is basically an open-air market and restaurants with a roof over its head. You'll find plenty of souvenirs shops inside but the real attraction is the food. The market is home to many great restaurants, but my Uruguayan friends all told me to go to El
There’s a lot of options for dining here. Good quality. Good option for a quick souvenir, too. Very close to the dock so you can be sure you are only a 5 minute away.
Compared to other mercados, this one has good parillas, better to sit at the bar so you see the cooks preparing your food, really nice atmosphere!

Great place to enjoy some good Argentinean/Uruguayan steaks. A bit pricey in my opinion (more expensive than what you would find in Buenos Aires) but food in Uruguay seems to be expensive in general. I'd walk around the market once to see what's available before choosing a

Great lunchtime choice with so many restaurant options to choose from. My friend is not a meat eater so we had a late lunch of fish skewers beautifully grilled and thoroughly tasty and sat at the counter. Very friendly team. Apologies that we didn’t note down the name of the

Among TOP 10 steak experiences in the world. I had wagyu in Tokio, steaks in the US, Spain, Brazil and so on ... given the importance of meat in tve history of Uruguay and given that these restaurants represent their way of having a steak in a resturant then if you pick the

You simply must go here for lunch or early dinner, open to 6.30. Lots of grill places which are used by the locals for lunch. Steaks and other meats and fish are cooked on an open barbecue and are amazing at a good price. The two we used takes credit cards so you get the 20%

Mercado del Puerto is a traditional place to eat Uruguayan BBQ and experience some cultural encounter at lunch time. Nowadays it is always full of tourists and locals. Food is fine; however some restaurants in the Mercado could do much better. Mercado del Puerto is still a

Take your time to stroll about. Remember that lunch time is the place to go as it closes in the late afternoon. Some restaurants however have an "outside the market" restaurant which is open for dinner. Feasting at bars saves half of the coperto charge. Oder medio y medio for

We had some time to spare before our return BuqueBus to Buenos Aires so we had a walk around this very vibrant market, restaurants, bars, shops, many open air in this covered market which enhances the atmosphere. Great fun

This place is BBQ heaven for those loving thick grilled steaks with a few potato chips on the side. While this type of food is not my style, the historic market setting is attractive & the atmosphere created by the cluster of many small restaurants is very pleasant indeed. We

Building dates from the late 1860’s and holds a number of retail shops, mainly tourist orientated, plus a large number of parrilla restaurants. We went for a walk down to the market on a Saturday at about 13.00 and the place was packed, mainly with locals eating. There were a
If you have only one meal to make im Montevideo. This is the place! An old and charming market, full of restaurants. I think there’s no way of made a bad decision. All of them seems delicious!
Visit mercado del puerto is a nice place to eat “asado” have many restaurants there you can see how prepared your bbq. varied menu and abundantly , you must go!

We went to this place about 11AM and they were preparing the bbq. We could see meat and vegetables on the grill, expectimg the fire to get bigger. We took great pictures, but the time to be is when people come to eat. Big clock upstairs
Wasn’t the best meat in the city but it was still a nice spot to visit. Architecturally interesting and a typical tourist stop.

This is one of the best tourist places in Montevideo. Great place to absorb the lively scene. Good food but mostly for the meat lovers and inexpensive compared to neighbouring Buenos Aires and especially to North America and Europe.

Only if you are a strict vegetarian you can skip this visit.The market was built in iron from Europe and fixed in place. You will find shops and restaurants, inside and outside the building. There is music, too. And art exhibitions around it. And nice shops from local artists.

This is one of the kind experiences in Montevideo. My recommendation is to sit in front of one of the "parrillas" where you will see all different parts (known and not...). Personnel is usually friendly and they will let you know what is each cut or serve. . You can enjoy and

We went there for visit and check out the lunch options. The market itself does not have any particular attraction since it has turned to accommodate several different eating places. Worth the visit, but a quick one.

This is the place to go and have a typical asado which means great quantities of meat. I managed to have some fish though. On top of the food the experience with the outside tables and the quaint stores is very typical

If you like BBQ this is the place to be! In here you will find many restaurants that serve the best meat in town, the best beer and lots of wine! Is in downtown Montevideo, in the "old City" and near the port. The best day to go is on Saturdays at noon. I don't believe it's

I was there during my last hours in my last day during a holiday, with my girlfriend, and it was totally worth the quick ride. The building probably dates from last century, but it is very well conservated, and offers a great choice of restaurants (for wines, spices and typical
No one single fruit or fish post here. 99% of the place if covered with parrillas (BBQs) serving mostly meat, chorizos, game, and limited seafood. Many locals, and also tourists. We enjoyed.

Best on weekends but also good during the week. Casual no hurry ambiance with lots to see. Can easily buy tickets for the city tour bus from here. Good place to meet others or sit at a restaurant or cafe and watch life go by. You can also stroll to see antiques, artist studios ,

The Mercado is in front of the port/ cruise terminal/ marina and has many restaurants with parrillas. It is a bit pricey but food is good and environment is nice (do not expect anything fancy though, it is rustic). We went on foot from the Plaza Independencia - not far but you

We visited as tourists and really enjoyed the rustic ambiance of the eateries, bars and shops. There are many parrilla choices that seem to be similarly priced with similar menus. We went on a weekday for lunch and had some terrific rib eye. Very flavorful and beautifully

We probably misunderstood what the Mercado is about and expected to see a normal market with fresh food, vegetables etc and some small resraurants and cafes. It's only about restaurants, bars and a few tourisric shops! Not particularly exciting as city landmark...

This is my favorite place to go in Montevideo. There are restaurants, bars and gift shops. The main building is old and original, amazing. You may eat mainly a variety of grilled meats and drinks the famous Uruguayan medio y medio, delicious sparkling wine! You can find groups
This is a very topical place to go for lunch. Or for dinner in my opinion El Palenque has the best meat and fish in montevideo

This is quite an interesting spot to visit, where you'll find a lot of restaurants, bars and gift shops. It's very quaint and has a cool atmosphere and some interesting antique artefacts, including a fascinating clock tower in the centre. However, the restaurants themselves are
Only lively place full of interesting fish to buy ..many good little restaurant open only until mid afternoon...the good is very good and there is fish to eat in town it is almost always meat

If you haven't been at Mercado del Puerto before then you have to go. There are several steakhouses and seafood restaurants located in one spot. Great food and great music plus some art is available from the locals at low prices. This is a must see for everybody visiting

This interesting market is just across the road from the port so a good place to visit from cruise ships. Mixture of artisan stalls and eateries that are cooking beef (what else) on open charcoal stoves. The only drawback is that this makes the place quite hot but there are

It is a very antique market , with a wide variety of restaurants , you can have the best parrilla in town !1, outside you can find several stores where you can buy souvenirs and handcrafts, it is open from 10: 00 am until 6:00 pm from monday through sunday

It's a wonderful place to buy meat or just simply eat in a professional meat restaurant . I have visited a few but always go back to El Palenque... to meet my friends for chorizos and asado or just a great steak or fish ! Perfection here !
Cozy little market with many excellent choices for a tradicional Uruguayan parrilla! There are also some stores for souvenirs and local handcrafts.

El Mercado is a must-visit. Plan to go at lunch time because it closes at 6 pm. Better on weekends but if you have time or a long break during the day then you will definitely enjoy it. The best is El Palenque but any place is as good.
When it comes to beef, Montevideo is the spot. The market is amazing with it smells and noise. My favorite place is estancia del puerto. They are nice and the food is perfect.

This is a place where good food meets good people, good atmosphere and excellent service! If you visit Montevideo and you want to taste the fabulous Urugayan meats... You must eat here... We order a "parrillada" for 4. We were 4 hungry adults... LOL... The amount of meat that

There are many restaurants to choose from .Cabana Veronica they serve you the medio y medio which is a typical drink consisting of white wine and champagne, while waiting for your table. Little pricier is El Plalenque superb food. One of the best rack of lamb ever had.
I saw this place on travel channel and decided to visit. Great place to eat steak, or should I say AMAZING steak? Also, you will find little stores where you can buy souvenirs and of course, alfajor!

Strongly suggest lunch on a Saturday at Mercado del Puerto, great Uruguayan beef, nice fun ambiance, a unique building ( ex train station ). Try the medio-medio, refreshing and tastes great. Half white sparkeling sweeter wine - half white wine. Enjoy the crazy crowd as well,
Busy, busy, busy. Open grills in most restaurants with the fire behind and they rake the coals forward to grill. Very good meats and ample plates. Cooked to order! Rare!!!!!!

A very unique place. A must experience. The open fire grills bring the taste of supreme Uruguayan meat to perfection. Might be tough for vegetarians or vegans, but many places have grilled vegetables and pasta. Carefully choose tue place where you eat. Great differences in
Was here during mother day so maybe not the best day to visit. Very busy place and for me at least not a relax moment to eat .

It is a very old and nice market, with several Barbacue Reataurants inside. You may order "Asado" the traditional Uruguayan meat, very tasty. Very good meat made on the fire and also potatoes made on the fire also. Is a very nice Restaurant, where you can seat inside the

this place is heaven for meat eaters, plenty of quality restaurants to chose from. I ate at La Chacra del Puerto, it was good to sit at the bar and watch the meats being cooked on the hot coals. The service was good, friendly and helpful. The meat was pure quality. Maybe a

I was apprehensive to see many comments about rude staff. However my experience was totally the opposite. I opted to eat at La Chacra del Puerto and was very well catered for. A very attentive waiter suggested the best steaks in the house. I chose to leave the table and sit at

There are a variety of parillas at the Mercado del Puerto. I’m very glad I chose La Chacra del Puerto. Bring your inner carnivore here. Try the chorizo (very tasty) and then go for the vacio (flank steak), which is tender and flavorful. If you're solo, and even if you're not, I

Great place to end our day tour of the City and it's many highlights. Recommended by the friendly lady at the Tourist Information and it did not disappoint. No visitor should miss this old port market building whose impressive wrought-iron superstructure shelters a gaggle of

Truly a fan place to go. Arquitecture from the beginning of last century, the old harbor market is a great place to go. Excellent meat restaurants that have the best meat in town. You don't have to go to overpriced restaurants with big names. This is the place to go. Either you
This place is incredible!!! The food is amazing. The atmosphere is great and the people are lovely! Everyone must try this at least once while in Uruguay. We went here three times!!

This is an excellent place to eat Plamplona or meat. All the places there are greats. Remember to drink with your asado one bottle or cup of Medio y Medio (half and half) is a lovely local drink. After your lunch the place is located near old city attractions and you can walk
Very interesting old train station building turned into a Market . If you really want to see the typical Uruguayan barbaque it is the place

To get a flavour of Montevideo you have to go here. Lots of good quality crafts and fabulous restaurants for both meat and fish. Walk around and explore some quaint squares and Piazzas. The main cathedral in MVD is a must.

How can meat be a tourist attraction? Come here and find out. It's a whole culture. Many parillas are assembled in this old market. Saddle up to a counter and order something delicious. Better not to sit at tables, where service is much slower and you can't see them cooking

The Mercado del Puerto is small but very charming. If your are not intending to have any meal there you'll see it all in less than 30 min. The restaurants offer many options, from the traditional CHIVITO to the also traditional PARRILADA. For the parrilada, you can have it

This is definately where you want to eat when in Montevideo, it looks great in here and the food is really good. Make sure you find a price you are happy with, some are much more expensive than others, plus they add a table charge. Avoid the table charge by sitting are the bar

After departing the cruise ship and through the security check there’s a Mercado across the avenue. It’s full of eateries that are outstanding There’s music to entertain you while enjoying grilled meat and vegetables, chicken, fish, sausage and more. It’s an exciting place to

Try the beef, try the wine, ask for a medio medio, half champagne half white wine. Awesome food, great music , make sure that you pay with a Visa card and ask for taxes to be reduce. Lots of stores and cultural events. We loved Montevideo
We had salmon there, and beef. Everything well prepared and fresh. The place is not for a formal dinner, but for tourist which want to try Uruguayan food. I recommend it.

I walked in as a solo traveler and was immediately accosted with over aggressive hawkers for the first restaurant...and then the next...and the next. Plenty of yelling and one grabbed my arm -- I am a big guy and wanted to hit him but thought better in a country where I am a
Interesting place. If you love meat this is Parilla heaven. Love the redevelopment taking the old market and making it a great lunch and meeting point.

Yes, there are some excellent parrilla eateries here for a major meal and great local suds before returning to "das boot". And some shops for fair priced Tee's, etc. too. But, the main feature is this great saved structure....look up, see that awesome clock, the rafters,

Good place to visit but I confess that I was expecting more from this market. In general is good, but the service in the restaurant we stayed was very bad. Anyway it is a mandatory place to visit if you are in Montevideu by leisure.
A feast for the senses. First time we came here, we enjoyed looking but for the second tie, we succumbed.... lived the beef feast and the closeup look at the barbecues working. Enjoy!

My wife and I had lunch there after the city tour. There are several restaurants with parrillas where you can get the authentic Uruguaian food ( great meat). We've ordered baby beef and picana which were tastefull. Good price for the meal ( USD 40 for 2 persons without dessert),

You might need to walk thru a sketchy street or two to get to it if you are coming down the walking street but it is well worth it. Surrounded by lots of restaurants (many inexpensive and very good) it first has the appearance of a tourist trap. But go in to the market and
This is so So Good for the Traditional BBQ. Quality of Food and Service are well above Standard and Ambience is Amazing

We stopped in Montevideo as part of a South American cruise and enjoyed visiting the city. If you are docked at the port, the Mercado provides a great stop for food and souvenirs. According to our local guide, many locals eat here as well - it is not just a tourist stop. While

This place has a great deal of hustle and bustle. It seems to be a converted train station and is located at the port. It's primarily food and drink on offer so there is plenty to choose from! All local foods. Some places offer the Chivito!! A pimped up steak sandwich... well
Fantastic open grills and nice artisan shops. The big drawback is that the grills and the market closes at 17.00. A pity that you cannot plan a dinner there.

The place is very nice to visit but, it is too hot the weather temp was 32 Celsius plus the heat from the fire pits it was like hell in there. They should install some kind of ventilation, fans with mist water or something. I don't know how people can enjoy a meal there sweating

Would not have left Montevideo without stopping at the Mercado. Get there early if you want to eat. The place is packed with tourists and locals alike. But be careful where you walk. The floors are uneven and can be dangerous.

We had lunch at one of the many parillas inside the market. I ordered a steak and my wife ordered lamb and we split them. Everything was delicious and the atmosphere was terrific. It was over 30C outside and with all the parillas we felt like we were being as grilled as the

Our tour bus said they were stopping for a half hour when we arrived here,which seemed too long a time for what we thought was to be a fruit and meat market. We could have stayed longer,as the upgrade done some years ago,has now established a mixed and eclectic market this city

The best Parrilla! You must have "parrilla" (BBQ) in Mercado Del Puerto. Try "médio y médio" (sparkly wine) or a great beer. They have the best meat in Uruguay. The menu has different kind of meat. Choose one kind of meat, "chorizo" (sausage), and provolone cheese. It is enough
Just opposite the port entrance is this great market and food area. There are both indoor and outdoor sections and it has a really buzzy atmosphere. Great for souvenirs!
Good food. A must to see and eat there. We was several time there and everytime the service and quality was at the best.
Wow, to watch them cook to order barbecue style and was your meat down with a bottle of local red! Doesn't get much better. And cheep too. My tip? Order one serve and share between two.
Mercado del Puerto is a vivid and awesome place to have lunch on Sundays! People there are all friendly! The food is really excellent! Exquisite meat! I truly recommend it!
The food choices are endless, the ambiance is great. A nice place to enjoy South American food and drink.

Carnivore's heaven. A little on the touristy side, but worth every penny. Don't go for the cheap cuts of meat. You get what you pay for. But if you get a Porterhouse on the bone, you will want to go straight to heaven. Another great thing is, they serve all their beers in 1

I went twice to be fair. But both times it seemed just desultory. A few hat stalls and souvenir places but not exactly throbbing. Met a lovely chap who was selling his painter dad's water colours. Delightful and I bought several that, in the cold light of day, I still like. Had

The best parrilla I have ever had. I can't wait to go to this place again. The atmosphere and its location make this place unique and a - must visit- for meat lovers. The quality of the food and service is excellent.

If tired of cruise ship food, you MUST go to Mercado del Puerto. Open Pits all around, lots of restaurants, but try to sit at the bar of an open pit one. Fun to watch, a hot place with delicious food. If you don't know what to eat, you can always point at an enormous array of

I had a different thought about what this place would be. Of course I imagined the tourist shops, but had no ideas that this place was mostly restaurants. The Mercados that I have visited in South America were truly places to buy fruits, vegetables, meat, seafood, etc. With
If you are a carnivore like myself this is an absolute must while in MV. The sights and sounds are enough to bring a grown man to tears of joy. There are so many options for great BBQ.
Is the best place for a nice saturday. You can eat until you cant walk anymore. Lots of bars and restaurant with musicians playing with guitars and singing just for you. It is a must see!

You have to love your meats if you dare to enter this place. You can smell the sizzling meat market as you stroll down through the streets of the old city taking in all the sights. Lets face it, it is without a doubt a vegetarians nightmare but after all it is what Uruguay is
Great place, lots and lots of good things and wrapped in an atmospheric package that never disappoints. It maybe a bit touristy, but its a good touristy.

This massive conglomeration of parrillas, wine stores, crafts vendors, is a must visit in the Old City! I can't recall if Saturday or Sunday is main day, but do find out and make a trip. Bring your appetitite.....the food is beyond belief and not that expensive. Highly

Mercado de Puerto, the old port markets is just opposite where the cruise ships berth in Montevideo. It is a large expanse under a high roof like an old English railway station. These days it is a restaurant precinct along with several tourist souvenir shops. Some of their

There is one thing you definitely should do in Montevideo: go for lunch or dinner at Mercado del Puerto! The ambience is great and the food very typical for Uruguay, that means a lot of meat... Prices are reasonable and people friendly.
Just a few blocks from the Old City is CentralMarket .I think it was my favorite dining place in our whole 3 week trip .Lots of people,and wonderful food.
Nothing really to see just maybe a lot of police in order to protect the tourists. Its visible that they are trying to clean it but it still takes time.

So there are lots of meat restaurants in one plaza. They will shout out to you to come and eat at their restaurant. Walk around first. I was told the prices are very bad there as far as food goes but I did not think that the prices were too high. Good to check out.

Lots of lunch restaurants to choose from, mostly steak. We had the empanadas from Carolinas, which is pretty famous. Then we came back at night and shared a ribeye steak. This is grass fed beef; very flavorful without a lot of fat.

This was the highlight of my time in Montevideo. There are 7-10 parillas here with large grills and lots of action. You can sit at the bar where you can see them do all the grilling or sit at a table. This was my first Padilla and I didn't know what to do. I just took a seat

We ended our walking tour at the Market. Outside you will find restaurants and craft stalls with seating, great for people watching. Inside food stalls mainly seafood and grilled meats on open fire. Most of the places will have local wine as well as alcohol purchase.

Different grills will try to get you to try their cuts, pastas and traditional Chivito al Plato (steak sandwich). Most are good but the very best is La Chacra del Puerto (see separate review). The market has a very nice architecture and also sells some wine and other local and

This market place is the most amazing assemblage of bars, restaurants, shops and atmosphere in all of Uruguay. The choice of places to eat is hard, but once seated at one of the many brasserie type barbeques you'll never forget the meal. Asado, the signature steak dish in

Filled with tourists having lunch. Just in front of Montevideo harbor and is packed with tourists having lunch. The place is very nice with lots of dining choices. Places look good, although we didn't try any.

I arrived here with a guided tour. The market ist basicly food and some small souvenirkiosks. The food isn't cheap at all but you have a lot of restaurants offering barbecue and so on. If you don't want to eat you don't have to go here I think. Its a noce interesting place but
We walked to the Mercado from our ship 15 mins approx;the stalls are mainly BBQ with lots of colourful veg; on display, it looked good, but a BIT SMOKEY!!

The mercado the Puerto is must place to eat parrillada (barbecue) you can get the most tasteful meats in Uruguay you can also shop around the market for good bargains, if you eat once you'll go again.

No doubts it's still a "must go" tourist destination as the building is impressive, the environment is very nice, the staff interacts with you in many languages and everything works to ensure tourists have a good time. Exactly because of this, don't take it as the main reference

This is the place with the best barbecue cooks in town, said our Hotel concierge. He also told us to order meat directly from the barbecue cook, avoiding all the extras that you pay while seating in a restaurant, but did not find a way to do that.

This place is fabulous there are a multitude of restaurants to choose from and also lots of stores inside and around the Mercado Puerto. We visited 3 times in the month that we where in Uruguay. My mom and I went to the same restaurant and sat at the bar both times (women

This used to be the fruits and vegetables market of the old town. Now it is the seat of a dozen of restaurants. They serve grilled beef and other types of meat. The location is nice, interesting, the food good, but the prices on the upper side for Montevideo. The old town is

If you love meat and south american steak, this place is heaven. There are several restaurants inside so you can choose which one you prefer. But again, everything is about meat! I'm not sure if it's really 'local'. It feels like it's mainly for visitors which is not a bad

Mercado del Puerto en Montevideo is a very interesting and fun place to visit. There are lots of shops and things to see in the surroundings, and the market itself is very colourful and inviting. There are many restaurants serving mostly "parrilla" meat. Some places are

Great grill with variety of meats. The market is a hall full of restaurants. You can take a table or sit at the counter (we did). Its worth a visit especially if you walk through the city historical center and you finish there with a good steak.
A great place if you are interested in food experiences-here you can try everything what is local and fresh. Quite similar to Markt Halle Neune in Berlin.

Esto es una parrillada. Delightful uruguyan barbecue at a historical building at the harbour. Squids, fishes, shrimps, sausages and, of course, lots of meat, from the most unusual to the prime steaks. Delicious in every moment, and the main reason for visiting the area.
I was a bit disappointed. I expected to find a mix of foodshops, bars and restaurants, while it turned out to be a hall full of parrilladas, mainly for tourists.

My husband has family in Uruguay and whenever we visit, this is top on our list, as it was this time. I love to eat in the Mercado itself as opposed to the restaurants outside. I love sitting at the counter (just my preference), looking at the meat on the grill right in front
If you are in Montevideo it is a good place to visit. A lot of different restaurants inside the same roof. I loved the ambient. It is good to have some drinks too.

We enjoy Mercado del Puerto by going to our favorite restaurants but recently they have opened several new shops featuring Uruguayan items. Hats, coats, scarves, wine etc., a great place to enjoy lunch, especially since the weather has not been the warmest.

We have visited Montevideo three times. All three times were on port calls from a cruise ship. We discovered Mercado del Puerto by following our noses on our second visit. Unfortunately, we had eaten a large breakfast on board the ship and we could only take photos of the
Supposed to be a train station being sent to Peru from England, would you believe! Lots of character & now full of lots of eating places & bars. Very lively. Lots of ganja being smoked nearby.
Great place to visit! Awesome restaurants, you have to eat at El Palenque. Interesting, fun & very Uruguayan style

Mercado del Puerto is the first attraction travellers coming to Montevideo by ship will see. Therefore it is a very touristy place. It is picturesque and hosts many parillada restaurants, but I would not choose to eat there. There are many nice restaurants around which do not
History and old style very well preserved. Many options to have very good food, especially meat (Uruguayan parrilla). Good place to walk around, get the Uruguayan history feeling.
Lots of places with typical food, crafts, wines etc. A little crowded and lots of smoke but fun. They sell very nice crafts at good prices

This is the place that most represents our spirit : plenty of meat ( ask for asado), tango and candombe music, special drink ( medio & medio) . Special atmosphere full of people. I recommend the restaurant El Palenque . the best day to go is Saturday noon

A mandatory stop in every trip to Montevideo, this is a picturesque place to visit, with a lot of parrilla (barbecue) available to see and appreciate. A typical beverage from Uruguay is famous in the market, the MEDIO MEDIO, a mix of 50% of white wine and 50% of champagne.

We loved the atmosphere of this place at lunch. Lots of little restaurants crammed into this market building, cooking meat meat and more meat! The sights and smells were amazing. Great vibe, as there seemed to be locals and tourists alike eating here.

If you want a nice and big meat to be prepared in front of you, definitely you wanna visit Mercado del Puerto. Constructed primarily to be a train station, the local became a food place with lots of nice restaurants. Worth the visit and the experience to eat in any of them.

In short: The place for a good meat in Montevideo, BUT the service can be quite problematic! You have to "fight" to be serviced, and since they have so many people, it might take a while. But once you get to sit, and order, you'll taste great food. It is really overpriced, so go

A place in need of renovation and just composed by restaurants: that is the Mercado del Puerto. Not to say that there are only restaurants, you find 2 or 3 souvenir stores inside but that's it. I really was expecting more attractions and things to see, maybe even to buy
Loads of parrillas with high prices and smoke. Very friendly environment and picturesque. Must go but also try out some neighborhood parrillas.

Sadly I came back too late to get a table for the daily feeding frenzy, however, earlier I had walked around and watched the preparation of the meat. If you enjoy markets and food preparation and meat you must come here.
We visited the place place twice. The first we only had drinks and second we tried one of the many restaurants. Great place to eat a steak.
The best way to see the original Montevideo. It is very beautiful much like what Buenos Aires used to be like 30 years ago!

Anthony Bourdain called this place "meatopia", I call it "carnivore heaven"! You can't go to Montevideo and not spend some time strolling through Mercado del Puerto. The sights, sounds, and mostly the smells are mouth-watering. I don't think it matters where you decide to

If you want to see people gathering in a informal way eating vorasciously beef, chicken, lamb and pork and all sort of sausages please go there and smell the food meters before entering. Good wines and beers too, and also fush and salads. Music is there and souvenirs. A 2 hs

If you're after a steak or some meat off a traditional Uruguayan BBQ (hot coal fire) then head here. We just had a quick wander around the market and our mouths were watering at the sight of what was on offer. There are a plenty of options and variations in price as well. Worth

Housed in what used to be a fisherman's market is a beef bonanza, or a pork party if you will. Stop by one of the neighboring tourist shops or craft stands before you enter the realm of las parrillas. I had no trouble finding gluten and dairy free sides for my delicious hunk of

We lived in Montevideo many years and this is a place we always take foreigners to. They would like to visit the entire place before deciding where to eat. Normally all restaurants serve wonderful meat and also they have more informal and formal sitting. This used to be a
A wide selection of barbecued meats at a reasonable price. Great place to eat with friends but it gets very busy at lunch time so arrive early if there is a big group of you. Definitely recommend!

Mercado del Puerto reminds me of the old school South American marketplaces you see in movies, so it was a real treat for me to actually visit one and experience it for myself. It's a worthwhile visit if you're looking for a different type of tourist spot to pass through.
Probably the best place to eat in Uruguay. Very unique place and the best steak and food anywhere. Definitely worth the visit. Prices are very reasonable.
Excellent barbecue, plenty to do if you want souvenirs. Really good place to come if it is cold or raining outside. A very good experience.

Has become an icon of Montevideo where you won't find too many places to go to. After a short walk on the peatonal you can get here and immerse into a huge warehouse that use to be Montevideo's central market and today is a gastronomic center. There's several parilla (grills) to

Port Market is a must for any kind of meeting. Um ride can be for a business lunch, a lunch with family or a simple tourist walk. The main meal at various restaurants in this place is meat. Eating grills beside the fire and the beautiful smell the roast is fantastic! I recommend
Great for a typical Uruguayan meal, several quality options here. Souvenirs can be acquired in the little shops around. You won't be disappointed.
Food, food and more food. Some little sales shops, but.. um skip on the shopping. Tons of great smells and food!!.

Your challenge should you chose to accept it is to east the mixed grill for two, don't bother with carbs just add a salad and a bottle of Medio d Medio for a true cultural experience. You can pretty much chose any restaurant they are all similar price, food and service but we

Aussie's love their BBQ's and this place is on steroids. It was pouring rain the day our ship docked so after walking the streets for some sightseeing and getting drenched what better way to warm up and dry out than enjoying some sensational cuts of meat all grilled over

If you visit Montevideo and didn't make it to Mercado del Puerto, you missed out. Best day to go is Saturday. It is full of people, great restaurants inside an old train station. Great food. You can't go wrong eating at any of the restaurants inside. Make sure you don't skip

The Old City is nice and charming and if you are looking for good fire-grilled meats this is the place to go to. There are a couple of restaurants but they basically have the same food. I would only go for lunch though because it is not a very safe neighbourhood at night.

This market is situated across from the ships and containbers at the Port of Montevideo.Though many were closed for winter,there were enough souvenir shops and food establishmets open to make it worthwhile.
It's ok. Nothing big. Very touristy. Not my taste. Nothing very special. Have to visit. Probably better restaurants for less money arround town.
The old market is open mon. to sat. from 9:00am to 16:00pm. There are different places to try the famous parrillada de carne and a place famous for its good and cheap empanadas. Go go go!!

Kind of popular market. To Brazilians visitors ir like our Central Market in São Paulo or CADEG in Rio. Good food, not expansive but not cheap. Accept all cards and main money worldwide (be careful with the exchange). There are traditional food that means you must be careful if
nice place. great restaurants at good prices. great place also to shoot photos. near buquebus terminal to and from buenos aires. better to go in the morning or afternoon. cloded in the evening

The place is nice, the old building is quite charming, there are many places to choose from for food. 90% of the food offer is meat and meat and more meat. A few places have pasta dishes of bbq veggies... Visited on a week day and was not crowded.

Outstanding market Was the port area for fish selling in the past Now host many restaurants that offer all kind of local food, mainly barbecue and fish Service is kind of touristic approach (with all shortcomings included)
A must go destination for lunching at Montevideo. In the Mercado you have many cuisines options at the food court, But i really recommend you to taste the uruguayan meat baked on the gaucho style.

Located very close to the cruise port, this was a great option to try local food. It was not busy at lunchtime on the day we were there. Many restaurants to select with very similar menus. Smells and smoke could be a real problem when the place was busy. No air conditioning

The mercado is full of nice restaurants where you can enjoy a real parrilla! The place gets really smoky, so be prepared to leave the place smelling like barbecue! But it worth it! Besides the place is super nice, happy environment! Don't miss it! Best barbecue ever!
