Had dinner at one of these restaurants with my fiancé... Couldn't tell you the name of the particular place as it escapes me... It's irrelevant anyway.. They all sell pretty much exactly the same thing! Amazing BBQ meats and wine with a few salads on the side + more but I only
The Mercado is full of local restaurants that mainly serve uruguayan BBQ. Just walk inside and pick the option you feel right for you :) Meat is awesome.
Completely worth a visit, specially over the weekend to have lunch, many grill options to have an incredible variety of Uruguayan meat cuts.
Worth a visit, good Uruguayan BBQ ang good quality food and service. In Montevideo you must go and visit this special place.
Delicious Uruguayan BBQ! You should try the provolone bbq cheese and any of their wonderful meat cuts. You should also try medio y medio, mixture of white whine and champagne.
Find excellent food cooked in a simple way and feed your senses with the environment. The contagious good vibe of the people will make the rest.

I had just travelled from Argentina and fell in love with their style of Asado but the Uruguayan version was divine. The pudding or pig's blood sausage, beef and lamb.... mouth watering, definitely this was my favourite place that I ate in Uruguay. Most of the restaurants in
Great food, a little touristy. Don't accept the first invitation to eat! Look around, find what looks the best, and then sit down. Go during peak times at lunch.
What was a market by de port, now is a trditional walk. Nice arquirecture. Lot of restaurants, parrilladas. Good quality food and wines. High prices that may or may not be justfied.

set in fantastic old railway station designed by Eiffel, there are loads of restaurants to choose from. we decided on one and sat at the bar, as opposed to taking a table. this way we could chat with the staff and watch our food being cooked on the huge barbecue. it was
Not your typical market, but a place full of delicious restaurants! So many choices; all look good. Fun place.
My wife is originally from Uruguay and we were holidaying with friends and a trip to Mercado del Puerto is a must, we all had great meals in a fantastic atmosphere.

I take all my turist friends who come visit Montevideo here. Its a place to enjoy typical food while you see how its cooked in the "parrilla". Also the famous Roldos, with its sanwiches and "Medio y Medio" wine drink.

It's all about the meat in the Meracdo del Puerto, with hunks of beef grilling away on hardwood fires. Stroll around a choose the spot that looks good to you. We actually ate just outside the covered market at El Quayro restaurant, where we had a bottle of Tannat wine and asado

I really can't understand how an attraction point of a country capital can be so messed with so many time to improve. It's well known as one of the best places to eat in Montevideo. It have some dozen of restaurants inside and still they can't find a way to organize things.

This shopping/browsing area is located in the port area of Montevideo. Go during the day and enjoy street vendors and an old market filled with different restaurants serving delicious meats "a la parrilla" (grilled). It's a feast for the eyes. Leave before dark.

This was my favorite spot in Montevideo. The aroma of all the meats cooking over wood fire grills is amazing. There were strolling musicians throughout. I recommend El Palenque for lunch. There is a line to get a table but to sit at the bar, just scope out people who are

The light and high glass ceilings make this place ideal for holding several BBQ pits with flames licking sausage, beef, pork, chicken, vegetables and more. It is a fast moving and crowded bustling place where the waiters move fast to serve beer and steak to a hungry crowd. This

This food market is a great combination of a food hall selling all sorts of tasty snacks, hams, etc and a number of good quality grocers. Definitely worth the short walk from the far north end of Playa de Canteras to grab food here.

Very old market , plenty of restaurants and barbecues. You can fine every kind of meal and different kinds of accomodations . Go only for lunch and Monday to Saturday only. Take care because is crowded so you must look for a place , especially if you are a group. Walk first for

Certainly, the building is charming. On Saturday afternoons, it is packed. I ate twice at restaurants in the mercado because the flat I was renting was around the corner. Average food. Average service. Higher prices that one should pay. That being said, the building is

If you're looking to get deep in the costumes and food of Uruguay you're in the right place! You have to try Asado and all sort of achuras; you cannot loose to try Medio y Medio de Roldos; great sweet wine.
You go here to consume as much deliciously barbecued meet as possible. If I lived here I would go here all the time. Incredibly delicious, fun and did I say delicious?

Lots of fun but a tourist trap! The meat is expensive and the toughest I have ever had! Make sure you don't buy the recommended combination of meats, it is so tough that unless you bring an extra set of teeth you will not be able to finish your meal, rather ask for a specific

Amazing steaks, salads, fries, house wine, bread, dessert (pancakes with dulce de leche and a crunch--yum, and espresso--but the best thing is the steak--best Ive ever eaten. (I had the "lomo") All of that food for two people was $56.00.

The Mercado is located in a touristy area of Montevideo where the cruise ships come in. We are staying in Montevideo for a week and normally avoid places packed with tourists. However, we found a fun and somewhat local scene at the Mercado, and had lunch at La Palenque/. You
Seems it was made for tourists. It has nice restaurants, but I was expecting something more connected to the people that live there.

I stumbled in here by accident because I was wandering around MVD without a map, and I was mesmerized! Food stalls everywhere! Lots of seating. Tons of people. Laughter, clinking of glasses, the sizzle of meats on the grill. I was alone, so I asked to sit right up at the

Dating back to the late 19th century this Gustav Eiffel designed market is located in the heart of the old port area of the city. Busy with tourists and locals alike, the reason most people visit is to enjoy one of the dozen or so parillas located inside. While table dining is
This was across from our hotel and we walked through several times. The place really gets busy when the cruise ships come to shore.
Great place to relax, walk around, talk with the locals, see the craftsman making their wares and pick up some souvenirs.
Mercado del Puerto is a place for meat lovers! You can't miss this experience! Be sure to go on an empty stomach and dont leave without finding the empanada stand.
The smell of barbecue struck us the moment we step in here. Almost every restaurant here serves barbecue! It is a quite interesting find in a mercado. Admist these, there are a few souvenir shops.
One of the few nice spots to visit in Montevideo. Nice to stroll around and sit down for some good meat and a medio-medio.

The area had restaurants, shops, sidewalk vendors, etc... and a tango dancing exhibit in front of one restaurant. Very interesting, and just what attracts tourists in droves from cruise ships like ours. The surrounding area is quite old, being the old city where the Spanish
This market must be your first lunch venue in Montevideo. It's where everyone - locals and tourists - go to wander round and eat great steak.

The meals that you get in this place are just huge but delicious. The lamb was a bit tough but the beef was good. I thought our meal was a bit large but I saw 2 couples who had 4 times as much as we had and they were thin people. The atmosphere inside was just great and to see
This is good local food. Big steaks and lovely meat. This is not a place for shopping, but for when you're hungry

If you are in Montevideo you need go to this place. Located in the neighborhood old of Montevideo and near the port, you have a lot of restaurants of barbecue to eat a very good Uruguayan food. Also you can getting a place to listening local music and drinking "medio y medio" a

Had the worst meal of trip to South America there. The service was as bad as the food. Couldn't cut the meat so chewing was a bit difficult. The meal for 4 of us was $130 US and only one of us had wine. It was a huge disappointment as we were really looking forward to a barbecue

The Mercado del Puerto is a must stop on any trip to Montevideo. I have been here 10 times on business and always make it a point to stop here at least once. Located at the port near the old city, it is a site to fill the senses. When you walk in you are bombarded with the
Wonderful local market with some great and inexpensive local eateries, very colorful and absolutely entertaining. Have a bottle of Patricia beer while you are there and have good fun!
Great for a parrillada, perfect for mixing with locals. Not open for dinner. Closes at 7 pm. Not an area to walk at night. Good wine!

It is a typical place to eat a Parilla. You can find several restaurants for all budgets and eat great meat, sausage and vegetables. You can find restaurants that accept credit cards (always good, considering the tax refund).

Beautiful architecture, amazing restaurants and a lot of options to eat. It's good to see all the restaurants because of the variates of the prices. There's also stores with crafts and stuffs. It's cool!

This is the one iconic place that I used to recommend to friends who were going to visit Montevideo. Located at the port of Montevideo, it features authentic eateries--or "parrilladas," as local open-fire barbeques are called. Locals eat every variety of meat and sausage along

Right outside the cruise terminal. Many places to eat and shop. A bit of a tourist trap. Prices are higher here. One major tip, use your credit card in the restaurant. They will do an instant rebate of the taxes. Can't do if you pay cash.

I just love old stuff and this place was perfect, an old market from back in the old shopping days. Plenty of restaurants, wines, and ice creams to try with a very original vibe. We sat at outside tables after having a looks around the inside , had s cold beer in the umbrellas
A bit crowded but with many restaurant options - majority with parillas. There is also an artisan market outside and the Carnival Museum closely that you may go as well.
I really enjoyed the whole event of going here. A vegetarians worst nightmare ! The steak was very good although I have had better. But just to see this place was enough. Loved it !

It's interesting place, already seen in some other cities ... at one place there are so many restaurants, many of them with the similar offer and pricing. It's a good idea to have a break there and short lunch while walking through old city of Monteveideo ....
When in Montevideo one must stop at the Mercado del Puerto. A lifely atmosphere, nice little restaurants and food stalls offering all sorts of local specialities at reasonable prices.

Meat lovers will want to visit Restaurants at Port Market (Mercado del Puerto)! The cast-iron Victorian structure holds many lovely restaurants opened at lunchtime, only a few at night. There many souvenir shops in the vicinity, but avoid changing money here, as the rates are
Amazing variety of meats to choose from. We had a delicious Asado mix and a bottle of wine - not super cheap but reasonable and so tasty ! A must visit
A big indoor area with dozens of traditional restaurants. Lots of fires in the kitchens as they prepare the parilla. A bit expensive but a very nice experience.

Straight off the ship this shopping area greets you. If you take the recommended walking tour then this is your first stop. Its fine but do shop around, there are plenty of shops and stalls in this city so don't spend all of your money too early.
It was painful to walk through for my vegetarian friend, but cool to see all the grilling. We actually got a great grilled vegetable plate at one restaurant (I had steak, too).

The Mercado del puerto is a great place to eat...meat and meat and more meat. I was here for three occasions. I recomend you to pick new restaurants each time. If you are a true carnivore, then this is the place for you.

They built it, but the trains didn't come. Now it's a market but more importantly, it's the home of amazing BBQ joints. The smells are incredible and the food is even better, you really can't make a bad choice.

This place is kind of touristy, but the food is good and well priced (if you know what to order). I stopped by for a quick lunch and ordered chorizo and provoleta. The portions were good and the prices reasonable. For good cuts of meat, I would probably go to a parrilla in a
OMG! This has been the best dining experience! What an amazing lunch. The meat was cooked to perfection. It was fun to watch the staff cook the meat.
ask first if they have a covercharge and service charge - otherwise there can be a nasty sting in the bill

These people love their barbecue. We have a three hour lunch so don't count on getting out of there quickly. Don't expect American style waiters rushing you for your order or your check. But the food and wine were fantastic

An easy walk from independence square and well worth it. Really good photo opportunities and a busy place, really interesting to walk around. As I am a vegetarian there was not a lot of options here for me so we did not eat here. This place seems touristy but also has a lot
We knew that Uruguayan beef was good, but add to it the ambiance of the Mercado del Puerto and the experience gets a kick up a few notches. A must visit when in Montevideo.

This place is one of the most interesting in all of Montevideo, the restaurants are all similar so it doesn't matter which one you pick. If you like steak this is the place, they are really great and the experience is very fun.

You can't miss the Palenque best meat there and one of the best in town. Best time is at midday. I believe it closed at night. Obvopiuosly go for the steaks and try molleja. Don't ask what it is jus ordr it, its partt of the cow... ENJOY,

Delicious food!! Look for busy parillas. A must do when in Montevideo. Make sure to share if ordering a steak. Bife de ojo (rib eye) is particularly delicious. Over the weekend there is a wait...only at lunch. They do not serve dinner

Walk down the main pedestrian street coming off of Independence Square. Turn rgiht at the end and walk down to the Mercado. not only is this great spot for meat and eats but this is a rapidly changing part of town you need to visit. Ten yerars from now it will be completely

What can I say other then amazing!! Mercado Del Puerto (port market) is quite simply a dinning Mecca containing numerous parrilas. Upon entering we were confronted by the smell of meat in the air and the hustle and bustle of all the different restaurants within the small area

Visiting Montevideo? This is a must go place. The barbecues offering all kind of cuts and vegetables. People from here and there. Sometimes a Cruise stopping by at the port, sometimes business men or football players, or even common people gathering for a nice piece of meat...
What a place! Grill shacks all around and chefs who've cooked meat all their lives showing you how it's done. Food amazing scenery even more so.

Warning - this place is CLOSED AT NIGHT! The market stall restaurants are closed at night and only a few restaurants outside the market are open at night. During the day however, this place is worth a visit. Great meat, although not a cheap eat.

We went to the market for lunch.....I found that it was as much a feast for the eyes as it was for the stomach. All the restaurants were set up with the barbecues pits and all the food arranged ready to be cooked. Was fun to look at them and see how each was a little
Enjoyed the day at the port and sitting down to an asado is a must. Plenty of restaurants to choose from. Only down side was the scarcity of public amenities in such a busy location.

Due to location, this is often the first stop for tourists visiting Montevideo. The ambience is always vibrant and the service has been good for me everytime. Only thing I would say is that the food is very overpriced for what you get. In my opinion there are far better options

In the middle of Ciudad Vieja, by the port, with pedestrian streets in the surroundings, Mercado del Puerto is an interesting view. Plenty of restaurants both outside and inside, the amazing smell of burning wood in the air and the chaos that outs to be called by several waiters
This is a good place to go for a good meat meal.The food here is fresh the service is friendly. You can pick your choice after walking around.

If you are walking around the old city in Montevideo, it will serve you well to walk towards El Mercado del Puerto! Plenty of different reataurants and authentic as it can be. Do you think they make good steaks in Argentina, check this place out!

Go. Just go! This is my review - if you are a foodie/meat lover this is the place for you! GO!Heaven on earth - this is not an exaggeration! The smell is mouth watering and the food is to die for. Go!! P.s We ate at Estancia Del Puerto inside the market - incredible food, great
Definitely worth a visit if you like steak and a good environment. Feels like you are in the ranch of gaúchos in the old Montevideo city.

This place is feast for the senses, vegetarians need not apply. The smell and smoke of parilladas can be well and truly before you even see the beautiful old building. Once in you become overwhelmed by the amazing smells of meats roasting. Eating venues are a plenty but as a

Mercado Del Puerto is located at the edge of Old Town in Montevideo. It is a typical food court with ancient architecture where all restaurants serve first class courses with meat. You can get more information about the place from tourist information across the entrance of the
Nice old market with plenty of typical restaurants. If you love good meat and fish, do not miss it. I recommend to go for lunch.

If you Love meat, then this is the place for you!! Meat is being cooked everywhere on wood fire grills. Pick your restaurant, order a plateau And tuck in!! Beware of The fatty guts And greasy sausages!! The black pudding was amazing!!

A must go in Montevideo. Yes it's touristy, yes some expensive but it's old school fun, tons of assortments of dishes, culture and It's a fabulous experience to go! Even if you don't eat, you can walk around and experience their culture. I had steak and my belly was happy,

I,m sorry for the couple that had such a bad time in el Mercado del Puerto. Their experience is the exception to the rule here. Ive been in Montevideo for the entire month walking the streets, taking buses, etc. and never had a problem. The Uruguayans are helpful and friendly

Another must do in MVD! The building alone is a slice of UY/MVD history plus you can peruse shops and plenty of restaurants ( parrillas/ steakhouses). I had lunch at the outdoor bar at Palenque (small picanha & stir fry veggies w/ glass of Tannat) and had a wonderful time.

I must warn unprevented tourists. I was told marvels about the place. In fact not only I was cheated I had to pay more than 130 bucks for a small piece ofgrilled beef but also sufferd a street robbery where my wife was injured. Three policemen watched doing absolutely nothing.

I guess anyone should visit this if they wanted to say that know Montevideo. Plenty of tourists, meat, wine, medio y medio and meat again. However, this is not the only place for good meat and food in the city, believe me.

The place is humming when a cruise ship is in so you may have to be aggressive getting a place to sit down. Numerous grills or parrilla serving up many cuts of meat and all excellently done. I had a plate of sausage and meat at Roll2. Mouth watering!!!

Even if you don't love meat as much as Uruguayans and Argentines do, go for the experience of having a huge steak for lunch because it's just part of the culture. All of the "restaurants" inside seem pretty much the same and probably are, so we went with one that had a really
Mercado del Puerto is a lovely place and a must visit in Montevideo. A bit pricey but the Adaso is delicious!

Is a very turistic and peculiar place with many barbecue restaurants. Is an old warehouse that know is a barbecue market. I dont recommend eating there, most locals dont eat there because is expensive and not the best meat in town. Just visit it, take pictures and go. If you
I liked very much this place. I walked around the market, I saw cool things and I drank the delicious Patricia surrounded by parrilla and ojo de bife. Very nice!

You dont have to have a map to find this place. j\Just follow the smell or barbequed meat over firewood fires and you will find this place if you are around the harbour area. I have only tried 2 of the places inside but to me it looks like you cant really fail to get a good

Not a real market, but rather a large building filled with restaurants.You can smell the grills from a couple blocks away and they smell wonderful. Upon entering, you'll notice each restaurant has a bounty of meats on large a central. We were served by a very nice gentleman! He

For the local market I confess I expected more. It's just a place full of restaurants. We went there at lunch time and there were lots of waiters trying to nail customers. The smell of smoke is very strong everywhere. Besides the restaurants? nothing.

This is an iconic place to visit. The old building is really nice with the old doors at inside you ll finde many bars, restaurants and places to drink. If you have time go and take lunch, excelents options> BBQ Opinion> at lunch is better than night, because the place will be

My hotel was near this attraction. This complex of restaurants is open only during the days with things closing down around 5pm. Their main meal is early afternoon and it can be packed during this time. At night, it's a different story. My suggestion is that you walk around
Great to sit at the bar while they BBQ these fresh cuts in front of you. Huge portion sizes and reasonable prices for such quality food. Delicious!

The old port docks have been turned into a huge indoor market full of bars and restaurants. There are a few shops as well. The place is clean and is well decorated. This is a great place to have a meal or just have a drink.
Lively bierhouse atmosphere, grilled meats and fish, good wines, an unique place to be remembered forever.
A really nice place in Montevideo! Excellent food and the marvellous Medio y Medio from Roldós, a delicious sparkling wine. Don´t miss the Empanadas Carolina either!
Love this place, the food the people and the wine Medio y Medio. Everyone is there to enjoy and have a relaxed time. Walk around for some traditional craft .

The place is an old market warehouse, with still and glass roof, filled in by lots of "open air" restaurants (meaning that inside the warehouse there are no walls and roof between one and the other restaurant) with gorgeous offer of grilled meet. Prices are reasonable, portions

Very good food, particularly anything concerning "asado". Very nice to be outside, but be warned that it is definitely more expensive than inside. Best to reserve ahead of time during week-ends. Pleasant to take a stroll all the way to Plaza Zavala and back to walk off all those

Got a mixed grill type but most of it was tripe and sweetbreads which were not the parts we wanted, The steaks looked nice, and our sausage, chicken and pork was sensational. The ribs were too fatty for my liking. I've had better for the price. Also don't split the bill if you

There were lots of stores and restaurants in this area of Montevideo that is located in the old city. We had to walk through some streets that made me hold on tighter to my bag. But nothing happened...

I must starting by saying: it's expensive! I, by myself, spent something around 700 pesos for a picanha beef with fries and a coke. Still, the experience is, indeed, amazing. You can't leave Montevideo without going there.

Mercado del Puerto, located neart the port, in the old city, is a must go if you want to experience a local environment, eat uruguayan meat and have a glass of Tannat, the uruguayan grape. It is a tourist place, therefore a bit overpriced, but worth the visit.

Great venue, classic old building, glass, cast iron, vaulted ceiling and dozens of charcoal bbq restaurants. Steaks, sausages, chorizo, chicken, prawns etc. We enjoyed ourselves a lot down here the beer was some of the best and coldest we have had in Sth America. The flavours
You could find a variety of animals on the grill there but the beef is simply heavenly. Much better than Argentina. Don't skip this place

It's s fantastic place for food, especially barbecued meats as the mercado is filled with them and packed with locals as well as cruisers. But, don't go for the shopping or to eat fish - we couldn't find either.

Regretfully nothing has been done to improve this place, which is a very nice glass and iron construction but calls for urgent improvements. We've been there on a Saturday, and the place was crowded with tourists from a cruise ship as well as others that were spending the

We ate at Roldos.We ask for chorizo, morcilla and riñon, a ham and cheese sandwich and 3 sodas. Full of fat and tasteless. i ate some and started to feel sick. I didn`t finish. I left the place with $u800 less and starving. Never again!
Great place to eat and very nice place outside and inside you can find places to eat typical port food and parrilla too

didn't eat lunch but it was an experience walking around seeing all the different types of meats ready to be grilled on large pit fires. Also are several good handicraft shops in the market and surrounding streets

You can not go to Montevideo and not go to Mercado del Puerto! No matter if you eat meat or not, this market is a must in town. There are great restaurants that all offer the famous Parrilla, a typical Uruguayan barbecue you will never again forget. Great meat. Nice atmosphere.

The market has a great atmosphere. Recommend timing your visit around lunchtime so you get a chance to enjoy a meal. Great lunchtime option if discovering/wandering the old town. If you're not hungry enough for a full meal I'd recommend picking up an empanadas from the small

Nice place to have lunch if you are walking around the old city of Montevideo. We were there late (around 16:00) and the place seemed to be closing down. Nevertheless we had a nice lunch (seafood mainly). There are a lot of options and the atmosphere was very nice.
It's a good atmosphere, an old and beautiful one. Also, a good place to eat. You have to try the meats, it's very nice. You must arrive early, the place gets too crowded at 1:00 PM.

You can not visit Montevideo without visiting this unique place. It is a very old market that has being changing through the years to become one of the more typical and original places in the city. Right in the old city, near the harbour, you can find there a great variety of

This place is central to any trip to Montevideo. The open barbecues are amazing and depending where you eat, it can also be a cheap place. If you sit at a counter to eat, it is cheaper and then can see the cooks at work. However, more difficult to have a chat with friends as all
One of the "must do" in Montevideo. Very good place to eat and buy souvenirs at the street. Some street arts are shown at the weekends.
its absolutely great eat here! i can’t describe the vibe ! i travel to Montevideo almost 10 times a year and its my to go place!

This lovely old building has been converted into a place to eat meat. there are over 20 restaurants each one boasting of having more cuts on the open hearth brazier than the next one. Some of the classier joints have added Lamb and suckling to the normal fare of beef. The locals

Not sure why this is down as Shopping in TA - when we visited it late afternoon, it was all restaurants. We sat at the bar counter at Veronica's & watched it all happening. Scrumptious baby beef & grilled salmon thank you. Wonderful atmosphere. Yes, it's full of tourists, but

text.wiki:
Carlos Thays (August 20, 1849 – January 31, 1934) was a French-Argentine landscape architect, and a student of French landscape architect Édouard André.


== Biography ==
Born Jules Charles Thays in Paris, France in 1849, Carlos Thays arrived in Argentina in 1889, after he was recommended by Jean Alphand to Argentine pioneer Miguel Crisol, who contracted Thays to design Sarmiento Park in Córdoba. During his time in Córdoba Thays became infatuated with the young country and decided to spend the rest of his life in Argentina. After moving to Buenos Aires he was named the city's Director of Parks & Walkways in 1891. This position gave him significant influence over the design of the city's open spaces, and his legacy is still strongly felt in the city's open spaces today.
Major projects included tree planting along streets, remodeling and designing public plazas and walkways as well as designing completely new parks and expanding older ones. Major parks and plazas that particularly show Thays influence on Buenos Aires include the parks Centenario, Lezama, Patricios, Barrancas de Belgrano and the plazas Constitución, Congreso, and Mayo. Thays' French heritage is reflected in many of his designs, in so far that Buenos Aires' parks and plazas are often compared to similar designs in Paris.
One of Thays' largest undertakings was the Parque Tres de Febrero, a sweeping area of open land covering several square kilometers filled with thousands of trees, flowers, many fountains, and monuments in the barrio of Palermo.
A pet project of his was the Buenos Aires Botanical Garden, for which he petitioned the city government to set aside land (almost 8 hectares), which he designed in sections to display plants organised by continent, with a large section devoted to the native plants of Argentina, which were ignored in garden-making at the time. The garden has the first Ginkgo biloba planted in Argentina. Completed in 1898, it bears his name, the Jardín Botánico Carlos Thays de la Ciudad Autónoma de Buenos Aires. One greenhouse, was first erected at the Paris Exposition of 1889 and brought in sections from France to be reassembled, one of five in the garden. A brick house in the English Gothic Revival style, in which he lived during the construction and planting of the garden, now houses the herbarium and a small botanical library.

While Thays worked primarily in Buenos Aires throughout the years he also worked on many civic projects in other areas of Argentina, remodeling the Parque Sarmiento), Córdoba, designing the Parque Urquiza in Parana, Entre Rios, Parque 9 de Julio in San Miguel de Tucumán, the Parque de la Independencia in Rosario, and the Parque San Martin in Mendoza. Thays also designed the grounds of the luxurious Club Hotel de la Ventana, near Sierra de La Ventana in Buenos Aires Province. Work outside Argentina included the urban planning of the residential neighborhood of Carrasco, aid in the planning of the Parque Rodó, and the design of the Plaza Cagancha and Plaza Independencia in Montevideo, Uruguay.Thays worked most extensively in Buenos Aires precisely at a period in the city's history where it was growing extremely fast as a result of immigration, especially from Spain and Italy. It is often noted that had Thays not insisted on high standards of design and frequent open spaces, many of the city's current open spaces would probably not exist.
Next to the Perito Francisco Moreno and other prominent figures founded July 4, 1912 Boy Scouts Association of Argentina.
Thays died in Buenos Aires in 1934.
