trip: Also known as Plaza Constitucion it is a nice shady square. Ornate fountain in the centre and a number of bars/eateries around the perimeter.

This small tree-shaded square in Montevideo’s Ciudad Vieja (Old City) is the city’s oldest. I can’t determine why it is called Plaza Matriz. (Someone’s name?) Everyone seems to know it, though, as Plaza Constitution (Constitution Square), named such in honor of the Spanish

This small leafy square is a focal point of the old town of Montevideo and much more appealing than the larger Plaza Independencia a short walk away. A number of cafes and restaurants have tables spilling out onto the square which also attracts a few craft stalls and street
One of the more picturesque plazas in the old town with some good restaurants on Sarandi street which runs next to it. Some people were singing there when we passed by one time.

this is a MUST in your visit to the city. Check info about the fountain and facts of the square or get some help from local tour guides for an enjoyable visit to this square and surrounding buildings!

If you want a tour of the old city, this is definitely one of your main stops. It is a large plaza with beautiful and historic buildings all around you. The gate or "door" to the old city is on one end and there is a large monument dedicated to Uruguayan hero José Artigas on

This square is very nice. It has a fountain in the middle and lots and lots os trees ... it's very green. It's small but with the overhanging branches it has a cozy feel about it. It is the oldest plaza in Montevideo. There are lots of benches so it's nice to get a cup of

It was quite relaxing spending time here. Plaza Constitución (Constitution Square), also known as Plaza Matriz, is the oldest plaza in Montevideo. It is located in the first part of the city that was built: Ciudad Vieja. The Montevideo Metropolitan Cathedral and the Montevideo
Small pretty square in the old town. Street vendors selling souvenirs and antiques. Lots of cafes nearby. Worth a stop to rest tired feet while walking through the old town.
This square is very beautiful and elegant one. In the middle there is a superb fountain, then a lot of platans and the cathedral behind them.
Historical place at the city , near the Cathedral, surrounded by shops and restaurant. You can spend a few hours visiting and taking pictures.

Lovely little square close to the main cathedral, surrounded by shops and cafes. This place seems to be the heartbeat of the Old Town - street vendors sell their wares around the fountain, military band plays their music there and there is generally hustle and bustle around it.
Plaza Matriz or Constitution Square; small basic plaza which offers a bit of shade by day. Full of drug users by night.

We fell across this Plaza whilst walking between locations. A great location to stop and catch the views of the beautiful features of the Plaza. The tree canopy of excellent and stops most of the sun from penetrating, providing great shade and a cool location to sit and ponder.

My materials referred to the plaza as Constitution Plaza. Whatever the name, it is a pleasant place. The Metropolitan Cathedral faces the square, anchoring its west side. In its center is a nice fountain. Located in the Ciudad Vieja, it is the city’s oldest plaza. It has the

I was there on a Sunday morning and this place were pack with antique booth and antique buyer. It is nice to have a stroll and look around at those items sold on the booth. Surely it bring back the good ole days when looking at it.

if you visit Montevideo do pay a visit to this place. You will find very good restaurants, a mini flea market and you can walk by seeing the ancient houses of old Montevideo. Safe and quiet is a most enjoyable visit.
This pretty park is in the middle of the older part of town and the business area. Lots of people sit outside and eat lunch and there are some vendors with things to sell. Nice experience.
This big park and square is in the middle of town and is a focal point. Lots of places to eat and drink all around. And some people selling stuff.

A real center of public life in the old city. With a beautiful old marble fountain in the center, shade trees and plenty of benches it's a great place to chill. Peatonal Sarandi forms one side of the square so all kinds of amenities are just steps away. Grab a bottle of beer

This is centrally located in the old town. Always smells of weed so move on if that offends you. You'll find some booths set up with people selling antiques and other items, seemed like they were there each day. On one side of square you'll find a large fancy church. Another

Plaza Matriz is situated not very far away from Plaza Independencia, and if you intend to explore the city by walking, you will no doubt find your way here. It is a very tranquil place to be, with lots of trees and shade from a hot summer day.

we came across the square, while walking in the old town. Sat for a while in the shade, it was 35c. Plenty of benches here. Lovely fountain as the center peice. Also here was a small market, with stalls selling all sorst of stuff, including old cameras, helmets, daggers!, coins,
A beautiful plaza shaded by tall stately plane trees....we were there on a Saturday morning and there was a market that had some interesting finds.

We stayed nine nights at a hotel three blocks from Plaza Matriz so we were able to see it many times during our stay as we walked the area. The Metropolitan Cathedral dominates the plaza and is worth walking through. Many cafes make it a fun place to take a break during a long

Plaza Matriz has it all. A grand Cathedral. Shade trees. Statues. Fast food, pubs and street side restaurants. Pedestrian only streets. Souvenier shops and stands. Food carts. Buskers. What more could you ask for.

With the Cathedral on one side, this little square (on our map called Plaza Constitucion) provides shade and seating but for us it was interesting for its antiques and bric-a-brac market. All sorts of things were available for reasonable prices. Also plenty of regular type

Great little park. A lot of people doing a variety of things from skating to singing to whatever you can think. Clean, safe, places to sit down and relax. Solid area for a snack or if you brought a lunch.
Right in front of the Cathedral and filled with bustling locals anytime of the day. Great public market filled with antiques on weekends

Constitution Plaza dates back to early Montevideo with Cathedral Matriz on one corner. There are many mature trees providing shade and a central fountain. When we visited there were a number of vendors set up in one section selling antiques and souvenirs. I must be getting old

After walking around Montevideo aimlessly for hours Plaza Matriz (Plaza Constitucion) was charming surprise. For the first time it was possible to find something to buy on many stalls selling "antiques". My husband couldn't resist buying a couple mathematics books more than 100

This is a square in front of the cathedral in the heart of the old town. It's very leafy and a good place to sit down. We came here on Saturday on a recommendation that there was a big market but it was no bigger than we'd seen on the Saturday. A lot of souvenirs and antiques

Great lunch and fantastic service at very reasonable price. The ambiance is relaxed and all the personnel very friendly.

text.wiki:
Juan Manuel Blanes Municipal Museum of the Arts (Spanish: Museo de Bellas Artes Juan Manuel Blanes) is the name of a municipal museum in Prado, Montevideo, Uruguay.


== Location and history ==

The Juan Manuel Blanes Municipal Museum of the Arts is located at Avenida Millan 4015, in the neighbourhood of Prado, Montevideo, in a Palladian villa designated a National Heritage Site in 1975. The villa was originally designed in 1870 by Juan Alberto Capurro, an engineer trained at the Turin Polytechnic, for the then-owner Dr. Juan Battista Raffo. The surrounding garden reveals elements of French landscape design. The municipality acquired the villa in 1929, when it commissioned the architect Eugenio Baroffio to renovate and expand the building. Baroffio maintained the eclecticism of the original design, leaving the facade intact. The museum was founded in 1930, coinciding with the 100th anniversary of the first Constitution of Uruguay, and named after the patriotic Uruguayan artist, Juan Manuel Blanes.


== Park and gardens ==
This property has a big park full of ancient trees, on the shore of the Miguelete Creek.
Behind the museum can be found the Japanese Garden.


== Collections ==
The museum displays Uruguayan art ranging from the nation's founding to the present day, including the works of Juan Manuel Blanes, Pedro Figari, Rafael Barradas, José Cúneo, and Carlos González.


== Hours and operation ==
The museum is open from noon to 5:45 p.m. every day from Tuesday through Sunday. It does not charge admission.


== See also ==
List of museums in Uruguay
Parque Prado


== References ==


== External links ==
Official website
