As cathedrals go, this is one of the more understated ones. We didn’t aim to end up here but we found it as we walked around the old town. It is not very big and free to enter. There is a nice stained glass window to see and the altar is pretty.

This is the main Catholic church in Montevideo. It is located across from Plaza Matriz-also known as the Plaza of the Constitution. Attended Mass here which was held in the chapel and not in the main part of the church. Unfortunately, Uruguayans are the least religious of the

We had 15 minutes here on our cruise ship shore excursion, and that was plenty. Catedral de Montevideo, the city’s oldest public building, was completed in 1799. Of note: it’s two domed bell towers and its unique copper-hued main altar. It fronts on Plaza Matriz (see my

We try our best to find at least a couple of churches and cathedrals to check out in every city we visit. Glad we found this one. Very understated yet beautiful. As I think about it, the understated vibe is part of the charm.
The Cathedral is well worth a visit to see the simplicity that makes it quite spectacular. So much to see and take in.
The building is very ornate. There are very important figures buried here. The altar is magnificent.
Centrally located, this church was very nice, and surely worth a visit. There was not so much else special to see in Montevideo.
Montevideo is not a particularly religious country so this cathedral is unusual for the city and is in the heart of old town. It’s nothing terribly special but still worth a visit.

Unlike many Cathedrals that we have seen on various tours in numerous countries, this one is more simple and refined.....not overdone to the extent that one questions why the money spent is not being put to better use elsewhere. We enjoyed our visit.

It resembles the European cathedrals so you feel like "it's one more". Located in the Sarandi in Old Town, one of the places that you have to go if doing the old town walk. It is a nice place but not very big. Your interest level will determine how long you'll be inside.
Impressive architecture inside church. Quiet place to sit, rest and reflect after walking for hours. Appreciate the generosity of the church to keep doors open for all.
In Old Town Montevideo, beautiful building and quite preserved, although is evident that repairs are in constant need.

Only viewed from the outside unfortunately, although the architecture is stunning. Worth more of a look, although my time was limited ; always next year when I am likely to be back. Local transport comes within yards of the building so access is no issue

Beautiful building with very impressive interior. Lots of marble, statues and paintings. For those of Catholic denomination a very special place to visit. For those of other faiths still worth a look for shear beauty and opulence.

Dating from 1790, the cathedral is the main Roman Catholic church of the city and the seat of the archdiocese. Its altar in copper hues is unique. Something I had never seen before was a priest waiting in a confession, reading a book, waiting for penitents. The church is
This Cathedral, which is located in the heart of Montevideo, is the monumental city cathedral which began in 1790. Featuring Neoclassical architecture & several tombs.

The cathedral is quite large inside with a central knave and two decorated side aisles. It is , overall, quite plain really. Inside the door on both sides are large marble statues of former bishops. The altar is quite interesting too.

It was a nice stop at this "main cathedral" of the city with some gold-glittered shrines (actually liked these "golden mini-pillars" on those shrines which was kind of a unique feature seen only here among many beautiful shrines that I saw in many main cathedrals of the South
Impressive architecture and awesome daily mass in Spanish at 12:05 PM. Votive candles are available for donation in memorial of loved ones as well.
We went on a Saturday morning. The church is lovely inside, with truly beautiful statuary and a large baptismal chapel.
We stopped here during a Montevideo tour and enjoyed the church. It is beautiful inside with stained glass windows and impressive altar. Constitution Square is also a scenic place.
From the outside you may well pass by but it certainly worth a look inside - Nothing fantastic but definitely worth a look

This Cathedral is very understated from the outside, but extremely beautiful and ornate on the inside. There are some magnificent stain glass windows, and the workmanship in the altar areas is quite spectacular. Photos are allowed except in one area. It is free entry. You will

This is a very pretty really old church in the old town. Has several dead people inside that are important to the history of the country. You can really get a feel of how things were going by how they build their churches. Great to know that Uruguay is a secular country
We did not see many cathedrals in the city, so this one was really worth seeing. Built in the Portuguese style, it is situated at Plaza Matriz and is easily walkable from Plaza Independencia.

Popped in, as we usually do when ever we visit a new city. Not much from the outside, But so lovely inside. Dates from 1790, and is the main catholic place of worship in the city.Along with the main altar, there are many side altars, and tombs of past archbishops

What a spectacular Cathedral,, what made It so special, was organ playing and quier in the background, We took some great photo's in and out, it's a must for most to visit on your tour, easy to find in the main sqare , you'll also find the new and old presidential palace
It is really nice and cozy. This cathedral is very beautiful and the mass is great. It is free. I recommend.
Very nicely preserved and maintained church! Active service mixes with streaming tourists. No fee to enter!

A relatively simple exterior facing onto the central square of Montevideo. The surprisingly spacious, ornate, yet tranquil interior has mosaic flooring, stained glass windows, marble columns and multiple religious artworks.

Facing the plaza Constitucion with its cafes and market this cathedral gives more than a peaceful bolt hole. It is full of interest with its side chambers of stunning architectural features and textural works. Well worth a visit and far more impressive on the inside.
We stepped inside to see how they do cathedrals in this country. Nice enough with some huge sculptures. Not overly-decorated,
Typical city Cathedral right near the centre square of Montevideo. It is set in it's own park square. Inside is typical, and easy to walk around.

It is lighter and brighter than some cathedrals as it is mostly light coloured stone used in the construction. At first sight it looks a bit plain, but on closer observation there are some intricate memorials, many to important people, and other details such as carvings that

Built during the Spanish colonial era , the cathedral keeps the tombs of several important figures in Uruguay’s history. The church is definitely worth a visit for anyone who enjoys architecture, the mosaic tile floor is beautiful, The exterior is not so beauty but the
Of all the churches I visited, this one is the worst of all, very dirty and many people asking for money outside. Nothing to point out here.
Beautiful little place. Interesting history here. They have a lot of little things on display inside which I found to be quite a surprise. A popular stop on many different walking tours.
This cathedral , though a Roman Catholic one, as an air of Anglican worship place with all the artefacts and history monuments recorded in it. A wa

A stop along my walking tour, this cathedral stands out to me for its exterior simplicity. Learning about the Uruguayan separation of church and state and the relatively low numbers of believers in the country, it was interesting to see this manifested in the relative simplicity

Visited this Cathedral in April, was in the Central Plaza opposite the Cabildo and the square was quite busy but once inside the Cathedral it was so peaceful. The main altar and the side altar dedicated to the Virgin of Thirty-three were lovely.
This is the historical cathedral in Montevideo. The interior has lavish religious carvings in the apses.
you cannot visit Montevideo without going to la ciudad vieja. I visited the catedral because I wanted to show my kids where their great grandparents wed. Quite a place.
Love looking at the artwork and architecture inside the churches and cathedrals and this one didn’t disappoint. Well worth a visit.
The most important church in Uruguay. Well attended service in a side chapel on a Wednesday afternoon. Very peaceful house of worship in the Old Town, in the middle of the pedestrian area.
This cathedral is suitably imposing. Lots of marble on the columns and statues and some colour down the back, where you can also see the stained glass in the dome. More impressive than Buenos Aires'.
Went to this cathedral in la cuidad vieja very nice and peaceful place clean and an amazing history near a square and would recommend this to anyone
I love to visit sacred spaces in all countries I visit. This one was ornate, and historic. It was a peaceful place and one of the highlights of our visit to the city.
Went in to escape the rain. A lovely old building. Inside is nothing extraordinary but is worth a look.
A beautiful cathedral, good for a reflection pause during our travel. Lighted a candle and gave thanks for a blessed year.

Outside structure very nice, build arround 1800, with nice towers and 0ne big interesting clock. Inside 1 big altar and some small chapels. The catedral is quite big Very nice situated, in from of Plaza Matriz, where tourist are able to find antiques exhibition mostly every
Catedral Matriz is at Plaza Matriz square, on pedestrian street Peatonal Sarandi. Apart of the exterior, nothing inside really impressed me.
The Catedral Matrix is a somber structure but easily recognised a a place of worship and peace. The usual dress code of modest wear applies.

Old Catedral in Montevideo so differents from others catedrals of South America. Very interesting artefacts inside . Was opened from Monday to Saturday but closed on Sunday

An interesting and well kept Cathedral with lots if history to it. The interior is full of interesting artefacts and details and is peaceful as well if you want a time to reflect orange just think. The Plaza outside is a great place to stroll and explore.

Classical 18C catholic cathedral with all the trappings of the high church with renaissance overtones

The cathedral is located in the Ciudad Vieja neighborhood. I normally try to visit the cathedrals of the cities that I visit. This cathedral is not that different from other Catholic cathedrals. It has a nice sound system playing some church/monks music. You'll see some tombs,

The Cathedral is a must-visit when walking through the Ciudad Vieja (Old Town). It has a beautiful architecture and ornaments and it is a peaceful and quite place for pray or meditate in the city centre.
The cathedral is worth visiting more due to its cultural interest than to its architectural or decorative one.

I usually like visiting cathedrals. This one's just creepy given that my guide revealed that a former church official requested that he have his body cast in the statue erected in his memory (one on the left as you enter lying on an elevated funeral bed).
Very beautiful church. If you have time, please don't forget to visit this cathedral. We really enjoyed the place and it was an opportunity to pray.

Right off a really nice square it's worth taking some time out to pop inside here. It's really peaceful and uncommercialised as well as being beautiful. Cathedrals can all be a bit similar, but there's something about this one which avoids that. The interior is completely

Right off of Plaza Independencia, this beautiful cathedral has so much to see. There is even a baptismal font where Artega was baptized and functioned since 1753. At least six side altars, beautiful statuary. Music playing sets a rev entails mood. One hour to see it all
The outside structure of the Catedral Matriz has simple lines, the inside surprises with plenty pleasing details in an Italian neoclassic way.

We always enjoy going into cathedrals wherever we visit. It may seem typical to many but it does provide an historical perspective of any city you may be visiting. It had a very up-lifting character to the place, which serves the purpose for which it was built.

Not too much stood out here, as it was like any other cathedral. It was a little small, but very clean and they had music (monks chanting) which added to the ambiance. Stop by if you are near, but no need to go out of your way.
When in old town this church is a must see. Absolutely beautiful. Make sure to rub St.Peter's foot for luck.

This wonderful old church dates back a couple of hundred years. Inside tells a story through its monuments and tombs to bishops and priest through the years. we see polished marble floors and a unique carved alter. There are so many works of art making this a worthwhile stop.

While browsing trough the city, we hopped into the cathedral. Entrance is free, of course, so just hop in. The architecture is absolutely stunning, with its high arches and cool temperatures. Plenty of sculptures to gasp at.
It was Sunday morning and a mass was in session. We were quiet and didn't take pictures out of respect.
We stopped in for a few minutes. It is a beautiful cathedral and in great shape. Very typical historical cathedral.

This is a very well maintained beauthifu Cathedral across from Plaza Constitutiona. Besides the large main area, there are several side statues. A good place to view, rest, and relax. Would be cool on a sunny day.
Amazing old church, built in the early 1800s. Art, architecture, and finish is exquisite. Saturday evening mass at 5pm. No problem taking photos inside the church.
Amazing church with a beautiful interior and exterior. During October's Sundays Mass is at 11 o'clock.
It's quite nice to visit a relatively simple cathedral. The interior is very calm and spacious, with impressive marble and wood work. Take a look at the dome outside and admire the tile work.
Huge Catholic Cathederal, quite stunning even though it commands little respect nowadays in Uruguay. Not worth a special visit if you have access to Spanish Churches.

I like that they did not charge you to enter this cathedral. It's not massive nor particularly ornate but it has some pretty alters and statues dotted around. Not somewhere I would make a special visit to see but worth visiting if passing.
Very soothing feel to the place and perfect place to wander looking at impressive art and architecture.

If you saw it from the outside, you'll be unimpressed because it doesn't look like much on the outside, especially if you're viewing it from the park just in front of it. For this reason, others didn't want to bother with it, while I did. There are plenty of sculptures to see
This is a very beautiful cathedral - inside - the outside is rather plain. It has a lot of beautiful alters and statues, and the (fake) marble is also beautiful. Quickly seen though.
Beautiful Cathedral, a very calm place that you can spend some time to tune out and contemplate thoughts.
Similar to the cathedral in BA, pretty small potatoes - much too late to be interesting in terms of architecture and little if any art of interest.

Lovely cathedral from the early 1800s on the Plaza de Matriz. You don't need to spend too much time in side, but do bring your camera!

Not the fanciest cathedral I have visited, but still beautiful inside. It is a calm and peaceful place to go.
Beautiful Cathedral, worth visiting just to see the décor, architecture. Very calm and serene inside.
This is a pretty standard Catedral for this part of the world. If you have a few minutes pop in if not you're not missing a great deal.
Centuries old cathedral with several historical facts written in local heroes tombstone. Marbles pillars, old and huge wood sculpture are all around.
Very striking interior. Pretty dome. Chandeliers that are extremely ornate. Fairly easy to photograph, although a little dark.

My wife and I love to go to old churches. This was centrally located and we enjoyed seeing the contrasting art work.

Entering the cathedral shortly after the custodian unlocked the gates at 10Am we immediately saw our opportunity to see all of the cathedral before the 11Am service. It is well developed with several altars dedicated to Uroguay devotion.

Great looking cathedral. Nice ceilings, nice sculptures, chandeliers. Convenient as it is in the center of the old city. Worth seeing.

Very well kept and astonishing religious decoration, marble, wood and glass are mixed in elegant forms and colorful spaces. It is with no doubt a must to visit. Definitivamente preciosa Catedral en donde se mezclan vitrales, imágenes talladas y cultural bien mantenida.

The renovated neo classical Cathedral faces the Cabildo and is the venue for many of the city’s society weddings. Lots of hystory inside!. On the same side of the square you’ll find the Gurvich Museum, which contains a small collection of paintings, ceramics and wood carvings

Very European style Cathedral, side chapels and lots of Marble and gold. The stained glass windows are very high up but I photograohed as best I could. Definitely nicer inside than out and definitely a must visit on any city walking tour.

Very nice example of Spanish Colonial Architecture. Seems very well cared for and visited. Pretty. Located in Plaza Matriz, aka Plaza Constitución. Also next to restaurant El Corte, where president Bush dined during his state visit in 2007.

This is a must if in this area of town. We stopped by here one evening as a mass had just ended and the inside of the building was beautiful. Everything was taken care of very well and the details in the architecture was great.

The cathedral is worth a visit, it respires calm and even grandeur. The 'plaza' in front is kept clean, and on saturdays and sundays there is a small antique market.

Stunning Cathedral in the heart of the old town. Well worth a visit to have a look around and for some quiet reflection.

This catedral has a lot of history from Uruguay in general and Montevideo and surrounders in particular. Deserve a visit, and is well preserved.

text.wiki:
Plaza Fabini, or Plaza Ingeniero Juan Pedro Fabini, also known as Plaza del Entrevero, is a square of the Uruguayan capital, Montevideo. It is located on Montevideo's main avenue, 18 de Julio Avenue, in the barrio of Centro and on its north side starts Libertador Avenue.
Its main fountain has a bronze sculpture of José Belloni called 'El Entrevero', which acts as the monument to the unknown soldier. Under the square, there is a municipal exposition area called Subte Municipal.


== External links ==
IMM - Plaza Fabini
text.quote: Verdant plaza noted for its monumental fountain, Fuente del Entrevero, depicting a battle scene.
trip: This is one of Montevideo's friendly city square parks. Lovely to relax in for a while. On weekend nights, there is dancing in the front of the square, with live music (milonga).
This is an interesting square as you walk on avenida 18 julio. The buildings around it are very beautiful art nouveau examples.
This fountain is slightly a distance from the Independence Plaza. This plaza is a surely a great for an evening stroll especially for kids.
A nice park to stroll and relax in. You can enjoy the pretty fountain too. A nice place for photos. A good place for a picnic.

Of all of the beautiful plazas in Montevideo, Plaza Fabini has the most activity day and night, making it a wonderful place to relax, spend time, and people watch. The central fountain/statue is beautiful, there is lots of seating to hang out, and the La Passiva restaurant on

We went to this Plaza as I had read somewhere that the locals like to dance the tango here. Unfortunately this did not occur on the 2 occasions we visited, if it ever does. Park at least had a nice statue and fountain that was not a hero of the country on his horse.

This is a large, interesting sculpture sitting in the centre of a fountain, in the centre of a small square. Seems quite a lively spot as there are several cafes inside the plaza, many with outdoor seating. The modern art museum is also here.

While walking along the Av. 18 de Julio we found this square a perfect place to rest and watch the movement of people. There is a well crafted monument in the fountain that will render some nice pictures.
This is a interesting place downtown, nice garden, some shopping (local artcrafts around), some snakes nearby
A lovely place to escape to from the avenue - to just sit and watch the locals and the pigeons go about their days.

If you walk through 18 de Julio, the main downtown street the plaza is in the middle. You will go buy. Lots of doves, children and people siting around having a little break. For people who live around is the plaza they might go to relax.

After dinner I headed the other way on San Jose and then turned right and lo and behold I ran into this cool little park in the center of the town.... it's actually quite impressive and it seemed the locals were enjoying this place... just a stones throw from the high pressure,

The Plaza Fabini is a beautiful area of grass, trees and fountains on the main boulevard in Montevideo. It is a scenic place to sit and enjoy people watching and also the sounds of the fountains and the city.
Many locals resting here and visiting on benches, a cool oasis in the city. We enjoyed it very much!

Also known as "El Entrevero" (the melee), this powerful oversize ensmble pictures an all out clash between several mounted gauchos and indians. Each figure (including the incredible horses, is giving its all to the act of spearing, macing or otherwise destroying their chose
it is worth to walk around or simply just sit down and relax. You can find little cafes or restaurants close to this place. But if it is sunny it is really worth to relax here.
If you are going to Plaza Independencia, just walk for 5 minutes here and go on. It is only a regular fountain. Do not waste tour time, there are more interesting things to see in Montevideo.

Half way between “Plaza Cagancha” and “Plaza Independencia”, this square occupies a whole hectare, from “18 de Julio” to “Colonia” and from “Rio Negro” to “Julio Herrera y Obes” streets. It has two names: “Plaza Fabini”, from an engineer and politician named Juan Pedro Fabini
